videoTitle: Iceland experiences fourth volcanic eruption in three months | March 19, 2024
videoDescription: Today on CNN 10, we travel to Iceland, where evacuations are underway after a volcano erupted for the fourth time in three months. The current eruption is the most powerful yet. Then, we look at the high cost of a conspiracy theory about paper ballots for one Arizona county. And finally, we look at a bracket-style tournament to see which bears nap the best. All that and more on CNN10.

videoTitle: Here's how NASA wants to send humans back to the moon
videoDescription: NASA is planning to send humans back to the moon for the first time in over 50 years with the Artemis program. CNN's Rachel Crane explains everything you need to know about how NASA plans on getting humans onto the lunar surface and beyond.

videoTitle: The surprising history of New Mexican cuisine
videoDescription: It's not Tex-Mex and it's not Mexican. New Mexican cuisine is unique as goes back millennia. Today, the food is a fusion of Native American, Spanish and Anglo tastes.

videoTitle: Saving the world's penguins from extinction
videoDescription: Over half the world's penguin species are under threat. Global Penguin Society founder and Rolex Awards Associate Laureate Pablo García Borboroglu has dedicated his life to saving them.

videoTitle: Decoding the Queen's colorful style
videoDescription: As Britain's longest-reigning monarch, the Queen is both a cherished and consistent part of public life -- her image synonymous with stability and tradition to the British people.

videoTitle: 'This is where dope Black culture is': Inside Atlanta's influencer house
videoDescription: Welcome to Collab Crib, an influencer house made up of 10 young Black creators in Atlanta. They work, play, and some even live, inside this 8,500-square-foot mansion with one common goal: making it to the mainstream.

videoTitle: Bringing back wolves to a Portuguese valley
videoDescription: Pedro Prata is working to rewild the Coa Valley in Portugal, bringing back wild horses as a first step on the journey to returning wolves and lynx.

videoTitle: Tribal warriors become lion defenders
videoDescription: Tanzania's Ruaha National Park was once a hotspot for human-lion conflict. Now local tribesmen are trained to track and protect lions.

videoTitle: U.S. Soccer Makes A Change
videoDescription: North Korea is reporting its first major outbreak of Covid, more than 2 years after the pandemic began. U.S. Soccer has announced an agreement to provide equal pay and benefits to its men's and women's national teams. Adventurers have explored a Chinese sinkhole that contains an "ancient forest." And a swimmer in Alabama makes an unexpected discovery.

videoTitle: Attending School In A Different Country
videoDescription: What is it like for Ukrainian students to attend school in Poland, where lessons are taught in a different language? That's the focus of our first report today, which also discusses alleged war crimes in Ukraine. An upcoming review of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and an extension of the world's longest roller coaster are also featured.

videoTitle: A Visit To Chernobyl
videoDescription: An alarming discovery has been made at the scene of the worst nuclear accident in history. Today's show visits the Chernobyl power plant, where Russian forces that temporarily took over might have been exposed to high levels of radiation. China's strict Covid policies have apparently contributed to a food shortage in Shanghai. And an all-civilian space crew arrives at an orbiting laboratory for a 10-day mission.

videoTitle: Inside The World's Busiest Airport
videoDescription: Russian forces and NATO forces show off their military readiness in two locations outside of Ukraine. An American airport reclaims the title of "world's busiest" as travel ramps back up. We examine a day in the life of an air traffic controller. And the childhood home of a pop superstar goes up for sale.

videoTitle: A Conflict Over An Island
videoDescription: Could a potential conflict over the island of Taiwan spill over onto islands that are part of Japan? How is U.S. airline travel being affected by "understaffed and overworked" flight crews? And just how old is the oldest living dog in the world? Answers to these questions and more are featured on today's show.

videoTitle: What Is A Solar Cycle?
videoDescription: As the U.S. government plans to phase out the immigration rule known as Title 42, we're examining some widely differing responses from lawmakers and people who live in a U.S. city not far from the border with Mexico. As the Sun's activity impacts space weather, we're explaining its mysterious cycles. And researchers at MIT set their sights on evenly dividing an Oreo.

videoTitle: A Trip To Kenya
videoDescription: The Biden administration appeals a federal judge's decision to strike down a mask mandate on public transportation. Efforts ramp up in Kenya's Lamu Archipelago to clean and process ocean litter. A U.S. streaming video giant hopes changes will recapture subscribers. And a parking lot puddle becomes a tourist attraction in Minnesota.

videoTitle: What Are Soft Robots?
videoDescription: How is traveling into China like "entering a fortress"? A CNN reporter finds out, as China extends its Covid restrictions in Beijing. After that, we're exploring the advent of soft robots and some of the challenges encountered in creating them. And a towering, glass-bottomed bridge opens in Vietnam.

videoTitle: A Journey To The Coldest Continent
videoDescription: The U.S. Federal Reserve has raised interest rates by their greatest amount in 22 years, and we're explaining why. We're also reporting on the topic of U.S. weapons supplies to Ukraine -- and some concerns about them. And we're journeying to the coldest continent on Earth with a pilot who lands adventurers there.

videoTitle: How mountain bikers stay calm 3,600 feet in the air
videoDescription: Competitive mountain bikers blaze across inches of trail on the edge of thousand-foot mountains. To stay cool in competition, these athletes have strategies that can help us all face stressful challenges.

videoTitle: Female amputee athlete runs 104 marathons in 104 days
videoDescription: Imagine running a marathon every day... for 104 days in a row. Earlier this year, amputee ultrarunner Jacky Hunt-Broersma did just that﻿. ﻿Her impressive feat set an unofficial women's world record﻿.

videoTitle: 94% of women executives have this in common
videoDescription: 50 years after the passage of Title IX, women's participation in sports has grown enormously. Some studies suggest that playing sports can help women succeed in the boardroom as well.

videoTitle: Meet the parkour athletes defying fear and gravity at ﻿﻿Red Bull Art of Movement
videoDescription: Parkour's elite broke out their best moves at Red Bull's Art of Motion event. ﻿The Greek island of Astypalea provided a stunning backdrop for the freerunning competition.

videoTitle: Title IX: What it is and how it has changed over the decades
videoDescription: Title IX reaches far beyond sports. Watch to learn how the civil rights law, passed in 1972, has evolved over the decades to protect the rights of more than just athletes.

videoTitle: See Google Street View's new camera and the garage where the tech is built
videoDescription: Street View is turning 15 and Google is marking the occasion by rolling out a camera the company hopes will bring more of the world to users' living rooms.

videoTitle: Cliff diver Eleanor Smart wants to clean the world's beaches
videoDescription: Meet Eleanor Smart, the cliff diver with a mightier mission than just winning at her sport. Her workplace comprises stunning locales, but under the surface, Smart's been shocked by the extent of pollution in many locations, so she's on a mission to clean up the world's beaches.

videoTitle: Corgis, cannons and Union Jacks: See how the UK is celebrating the Queen's Jubilee
videoDescription: A four-day celebration has kicked off in the United Kingdom where thousands gathered to mark Queen Elizabeth II's Platinum Jubilee.

videoTitle: Monkeypox - what is it and should you be worried?
videoDescription: The Monkeypox virus is a less-severe cousin of the Smallpox virus. Dr Sanjay Gupta says it has been spreading among younger people as they are less likely to have been inoculated against Smallpox, which was eradicated in 1977.

videoTitle: A Tragedy In Texas
videoDescription: We begin with a brief report on a tragedy in Texas. That's followed by a look at rampant inflation and shortages in two countries on opposite sides of the Northern Hemisphere. From there, we cover the U.S. primary season, a mountain climbing record in Nepal, and a massive order of cheeseburgers.

videoTitle: Congress Discusses UFOs
videoDescription: After decades of neutrality, Finland and Sweden have applied for NATO membership; today's show explains why. For the first time in more than 50 years, the U.S. Congress has held a hearing into UFO sightings. A new virtual reality attachment aims to accurately restrict breathing. And a paper airplane championship shows just how far these crafts can fly.

videoTitle: A Historic Chess Match
videoDescription: A gloomy statistic from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control points to a record number of fatal drug overdoses in America. After a bit of chess trivia, we're looking back on a historic match between a man and a machine in 1997. And a worker in Brazil breaks his own world record for company loyalty.

videoTitle: Lower Lake Levels
videoDescription: U.S. President Joe Biden speaks on the topic of inflation, as gas prices hit a new record high. Bitcoin's value has dropped dramatically in recent months, but mining the cryptocurrency is in full swing. An ongoing drought in the American West brings down lake levels, threatening some livelihoods. And a tech company opens its first retail store.

videoTitle: Drought In The American West
videoDescription: New details have emerged from a shooting at a school in Uvalde, Texas, and we're reporting on what U.S. President Joe Biden and Texas Governor Greg Abbott said about the incident. An ongoing drought in the American West is bringing lake levels to historic lows. A conservation center in New Zealand aims to help penguins. And a relic of a bygone era is removed from Midtown Manhattan.

videoTitle: McDonald's Is Moving Out
videoDescription: Economists are increasingly sounding the alarm about the possibility of a recession: Why are they concerned? On the heels of an announcement that McDonald's would end its business in Russia, we're showing you a report from our archives on how things looked when its first restaurant there opened. And we're taking a stroll on the longest suspension footbridge in the world.

videoTitle: Password Problems
videoDescription: A billionaire is buying a social media company. The reasons why and the concerns surrounding the deal are all part of today's down-the-middle coverage on CNN 10. We're examining how the war in Ukraine could have rippling effects on food prices and supplies around the world. And we're looking at cyber "insecurity" and some newer approaches to getting account access.

videoTitle: Benefits Of A Little Exercise
videoDescription: A subtropical system stalls over South Africa, bringing tremendous amounts of rain and flooding to the eastern part of the country. Events in Eastern Europe threaten to deepen food insecurity in nations thousands of miles south. A new study suggests benefits to even limited exercise. And a meteor that arrived on Earth years ago might've originated outside the solar system.

videoTitle: Farming In America
videoDescription: Farming in America is one of today's main topics, as we explain what happens "between the war and the store": How does the conflict in Ukraine affect food prices across the Atlantic? We're also examining what both sides want for the war to end, and we're looking at signs that Russia's invasion is not going according to plan.

videoTitle: Explaining Rising Costs
videoDescription: The U.S. government has decided to ban imports of Russian energy commodities, and today's show begins by explaining what that means. With gas prices soaring, we're breaking down some reasons why food prices are also on the rise. And we're reporting on the effects of ongoing storms in eastern Australia.

videoTitle: The Global Space Race | December 7, 2021
videoDescription: With different countries around the world sending spacecraft into the unknown, a global space race appears to be heating up. With rampant food waste in America, companies are trying to find ways to prevent expired groceries from reaching landfills. And with the common bond of donuts, one friend helps another get a new home for the holidays.

videoTitle: Discussing The Debt Ceiling Debate | September 24, 2021
videoDescription: A standoff over the U.S. debt ceiling headlines our show this Friday. After a report on that, we're taking you to Thailand for a view of a centuries-old fishing tradition. Also featured: efforts to reduce food spoilage in Nigeria and some highlights of a robotics conference in China.

videoTitle: A Missile Test And A Food Delivery Problem | September 14, 2021
videoDescription: What is the significance of a purported cruise missile test by North Korea? That's today's first topic. We're also covering a lawsuit filed by food delivery companies against New York City. And we're looking at a restaurant's creative solution to an ongoing worker shortage.

videoTitle: A Fix For Food Delivery Trash?
videoDescription: Billions of single-use takeout containers end up in landfills every year. New food delivery startup, DeliverZero wants to change that with reusable containers.

videoTitle: Very Different Approaches | March 8, 2021
videoDescription: Different U.S. states take very different approaches when it comes to Covid restrictions. The leader of the Roman Catholic Church makes a historic visit to a Middle Eastern country. A Japanese centenarian, who's one of the oldest people on the planet, prepares to carry the Olympic torch. And drone robots make food deliveries on a Massachusetts campus.

videoTitle: Making Food From Air?
videoDescription:
In Finland, scientists are making an entirely new ingredient out of air, water and electricity -- and they hope it could revolutionize the way our food is produced.

Feeding an ever-growing population is putting a huge strain on the Earth's resources. Agriculture is one of the world's largest sources of greenhouse gases, with animal farming in particular responsible for 14.5% of the world's greenhouse gas emissions, mostly from beef and dairy cattle.

videoTitle: Food Bowls You Can Eat?
videoDescription:
Food packaging is filling up landfills and polluting our oceans, where materials like plastic and polystyrene can take centuries to decompose.

But one company might have a tasty solution to cut down our use of plastic dishware.

South African startup Munch Bowls has created a biodegradable bowl made from wheat, which you can eat as part of your meal. The bowls are vegan, can hold hot soup for up to five hours and have a shelf life of 15 months, according to the company.

videoTitle: What's For Dinner? Insects.
videoDescription: Many insects are nutritious and packed with protein. They could help feed the world and reduce the effects of food production on climate change.

videoTitle: News From Land And Sea | December 3, 2020
videoDescription: This Thursday, we're bringing you news from land and sea. Bushfires scorch large parts of an Australian island, and residents are concerned about the upcoming season on the mainland. Food workers help fishermen and the hungry in California. And a boater is rescued far from the Florida coast.

videoTitle: Could Mushrooms Be Key To Replacing Plastic?
videoDescription: Ecovative is growing alternatives to plastic out of mycelium, the root structure of mushrooms. The company says it can make building materials, packaging and potentially even foods that are sustainable and compostable.

videoTitle: Why Have A High-Tech Kitchen?
videoDescription: The microwave, which was invented after World War II, revolutionized cooking by heating food in seconds.  Now, experts say the kitchen is poised for yet another reinvention. The next wave will be fueled by smart appliances, voice technology and 3D printers.

videoTitle: Can You 3D Print Food?
videoDescription: Could 3D printed food be the future of food production?

videoTitle: What Happens To Your Body In Space?
videoDescription: Tour NASA's Johnson Space Center where everything from food, to space suits, to exercise routines are being designed so humans can survive in space.

videoTitle: Why Are Bees Disappearing Around The World?
videoDescription: Bees are critical for food pollination, but some of them are disappearing at an alarming rate. Go on an investigation and meet a man on a quest to find a bee that may already be extinct.

videoTitle: What's Triggering The Stock Market? | March 10, 2020
videoDescription: There were two main reasons why international stock markets plummeted on Monday, and today's show explains what they were and why they triggered a "circuit breaker." We're also showing you how a former NFL running back is helping fulfill the dream of his mother. And a food truck for dogs delivers chow in Virginia.

videoTitle: New Tech In The Fight To Protect Rhinos | February 13, 2020
videoDescription: Results from New Hampshire headline today's show, along with a quick explanation of why delegates matter. New technology is helping in the fight against poachers and the conservation of rhinos. Mushrooms are growing in popularity -- as both a food and a form of packaging. And mysterious radio signals are detected from deep space.

videoTitle: Treaty To Protect The Wreckage Of The Titanic | January 22, 2020
videoDescription: Welcome to a new edition of CNN 10! The first topic we're explaining today is the role of the Chief Justice of the United States in a Senate impeachment trial. That's followed by a report on an international treaty concerning the wreckage of the Titanic. And a new type of protein powder shows potential as a food source, but it has some significant drawbacks.

videoTitle: 50th Anniversary Of "One Giant Leap For Mankind" | March 14, 2019
videoDescription: Weather, fast food, and missions to the moon are three of our subjects today. You'll hear about a major winter storm that caused dramatic weather changes in the Rocky Mountains, and you'll see how some U.S. restaurant brands are making big bucks across the Pacific. And the release of a new film with recently restored footage coincides with the 50th anniversary of "one giant leap for mankind."

videoTitle: Water Crisis In Venezuela | March 18, 2019
videoDescription: Authorities in New Zealand investigate a shooting at two mosques, while mourners gather at the sites and beyond. A water crisis adds to the list of woes faced by people in Venezuela. Record flooding in Nebraska extends the effects of a "bomb cyclone." And a snowcat prowls the slopes of Colorado, looking to serve food to skiers.

videoTitle: Inside the U.S. Food Industry: Produce | April 19, 2019
videoDescription: Today's special edition features a look into the U.S. food industry. Our "Raw Ingredients" report examines produce: With Americans consuming 3 billion pounds of salad a year, what's being done to prevent foodborne illness? How stressed is the U.S. food industry, and to what extent has the practice of importing leafy greens changed? It's all featured this Friday.

videoTitle: Inside The U.S. Food Industry: Animals | April 22, 2019
videoDescription: Welcome to a special edition of CNN10! Today, we're taking you inside the U.S. food industry and focusing specifically on animal feed: What's in the diets of animals raised for food, and why might that matter to some consumers?

videoTitle: North Korea's Food Shortage | May 15, 2019
videoDescription: The United Nations says North Korea is facing a food shortage that could affect 40 percent of the population. India's marathon election is winding down, but the country is still fighting misinformation online. And scientists say the moon is shrinking like a grape shrinks to a raisin. These stories and more are featured today on CNN 10!

videoTitle: Yemen: World's Largest Humanitarian Crisis | May 21, 2019
videoDescription: In what the United Nations calls the world's largest humanitarian crisis, some of the aid that's been sent to Yemen is missing -- and there are indications it's being used as a sort of weapon. After a bit of ingredient trivia, we're reporting on a study that contrasts the dietary effects of ultraprocessed and unprocessed foods. And we're giving you a glimpse of what the world's largest teddy bear looks like.

videoTitle: Food Shortage in Cuba | May 22, 2019
videoDescription: Cuba is where we start today's show; the nation is facing a food shortage that's being influenced by events abroad. If you already knew how to spell bourrée, drahthaar, and aalii, you'll have no problem with our second story. And we're exploring the growing market for plant-based meat alternatives and explaining why the industry may face challenges in the years ahead.

videoTitle: A Full Harvest "Micromoon" | September 13, 2019
videoDescription: The Bahamian government updates its estimate on the number of people missing following Hurricane Dorian. A full, harvest "micromoon" coincides with a notorious date. And a CNN Hero helps others in her community by providing food, clothing and emotional support.

videoTitle: The Problem With Superbugs | November 15, 2019
videoDescription: Good news and bad news concerning "superbugs" are our first topics on Friday's show: How do antibiotics factor in, and what can be done about the issue? Another subject we're exploring is whether insects will catch on as a food source in the West. A new planetary lander for China and new office pet policies in Japan round out our last program of the week

videoTitle: Justin Trudeau Wins Another Term in Office | October 23, 2019
videoDescription: Canada's prime minister has won another term in office, but his party has lost its majority in Parliament. A significant opioid settlement has been reached in the United States, but thousands of legal cases remain. The ruins of World War II-era Japanese warships are located in the Pacific. And a pastor in North Carolina turns his food desert into a food oasis.

videoTitle: Three reasons gas prices are expected to stay high
videoDescription: Record setting gas prices show no signs of slowing down, CNN's Matt Egan explains why global issues are continuing to cause pain at the pump.

videoTitle: Thermal imaging reveals the lasting impact of racist housing policies
videoDescription: CNN's Derek Van Dam measures the surface temperatures in two Atlanta parks serving two different communities, and the results are staggering.

videoTitle: The U.S. Policy On Taiwan
videoDescription: President Biden stirs debate and controversy when commenting on Taiwan, but his administration says U.S. policy hasn't changed. A virus called monkeypox spreads to countries that aren't used to seeing it, but officials say people shouldn't panic. A European volcano puts on a spectacular light show. And a gullwing car makes history at auction.

videoTitle: What Is A Bear Market?
videoDescription: We're covering a lot of topics on today's show; they include U.S. aid to Ukraine, efforts to ease a baby formula shortage, rising fuel prices, and signs of a bear stock market. We're also having a bit of fun in Europe as the Tramdriver Championship tests operators' light-rail skills.

videoTitle: Infrastructure Concerns In America
videoDescription: How long will it be before U.S. stores are restocked with baby formula? The possible answer -- along with a look at infrastructure concerns in America -- are today's first topics. Efforts to conserve Andean condors and grow plants in lunar soil are the other subjects we're exploring this Wednesday.

videoTitle: What's With Whales In New York?
videoDescription: As Victory Day is marked in Russia and Ukraine, different leaders voice very different views about the two nations' ongoing war. On the road to an Alaskan resort community, a large landslide forces commuters to sail around. And off the coast of New York City, efforts are under way to keep tabs on the whales that are prevalent in the area.

videoTitle: What's Next? | December 8, 2020
videoDescription: U.S. politics and the vote certification process headline today's edition of CNN 10. Then, we're examining a skeleton believed to have belonged to a triceratops, and we're looking at some of the pros and cons of NASA's next planned moon mission. Finally, we land near the world's largest flower arrangement in Dubai.

videoTitle: The Pros And Cons Of 5G | April 9, 2019
videoDescription: First up this Tuesday on CNN 10: There's been a shakeup in the U.S. Department of Homeland Security. After we explain that, we're looking at politics and produce along the U.S. border with Mexico. Then, we're examining why the U.S. government has designated part of Iran's government as a foreign terrorist organization. And we're exploring the pros and cons of forthcoming 5G technology.

videoTitle: Politics And The Mueller Report | April 23, 2019
videoDescription: Our return to daily events coverage begins in Sri Lanka, where police are investigating a series of terrorist attacks that took place on Easter Sunday. From there, we're updating you on U.S. politics concerning the Mueller Report, and we're taking you inside a newly unveiled tomb in Egypt. A proposed change to an iconic American street rounds out today's coverage.

videoTitle: Elina Svitolina is on a 'mission' to help war-torn Ukraine
videoDescription: This month, Ukrainian tennis player Elina Svitolina became an ambassador of UNITED24. ﻿Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky launched U24 in the wake of the Russian invasion. ﻿The foundation is the main avenue for collecting charitable donations in support of Ukraine's defense.

videoTitle: Virtual Reality Inside A Molecule
videoDescription: For the first time in 20 years, a French president has been re-elected. Today's show looks at back at his first term and some of the challenges facing the country. Afterward, we're showing you how virtual reality has gotten a unique role in medical research. And we're stopping by a literary landmark to report on an upcoming record attempt.

videoTitle: How To Fix The Oscars?
videoDescription: A controversial statement concerning Russia's leader capped off President Biden's recent trip to Europe. Find out what was said, why it raised eyebrows, and what else the U.S. leader addressed in Poland. And following last night's Academy Awards, hear why some experts suggest the show will go on though it may never recover the ratings it once had.

videoTitle: Key Moments from the State of the Union
videoDescription: Highlights from the U.S. president's State of the Union speech and the opposing party's response are featured on today's show. Russia has stepped up its strikes in Ukraine, as a miles-long convoy of military equipment approaches the capital. And NASA says two galaxies are engaged in a cosmic game of tug-of-war.

videoTitle: Life During Wartime in Ukraine
videoDescription: American officials say the Russian advance in Ukraine has been slower than the Russian government expected. Today's show explains why and gives you a sense of what conditions are like for civilians in Ukraine. Afterward, we're reporting on U.S. President Joe Biden's nominee to the Supreme Court. And we're fetching some unique information about a damaged doghouse.

videoTitle: Selecting the next Supreme Court nominee
videoDescription: The U.S. Supreme Court confirmation process takes center stage today, as President Joe Biden prepares to announce his nominee to replace a retiring justice. Afterward, we're reporting on a trio of science stories: Two concern space, and one covers a volcanic eruption on Earth. Finally, a man earns a record for stacking M&Ms.

videoTitle: A game of chess
videoDescription: Russian troops are on the ground in Ukraine, and NATO's Western allies are sanctioning Russia’s economy. As Britain's Queen Elizabeth II fights a Covid infection, we're looking back at her meetings with a dozen U.S. presidents. A teenage chess prodigy defeats a 31-year-old champion. And a camera in the woods perfectly captures a wild wolf's howl.

videoTitle: Is It A Blizzard?
videoDescription:
There's a specific definition of the word "blizzard" -- did the storm that recently struck the U.S. Northeast fit the bill? There's an investigation taking place into what caused a bridge to collapse in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania just hours before President Biden visited the city. And there's a growing shortage of pilots in the U.S.; what's being done to address it?

Chapters:

videoTitle: One Year In Office | January 21, 2022
videoDescription: U.S. President Joe Biden's first year has been one of ups and downs; today's show recaps a news conference he gave this week and examines some reporters' questions going forward. Divers discuss a newly discovered coral reef near Tahiti. A 19-year-old pilot makes history in an around-the-world flight. And Disney fans line up for hours to buy a special container of popcorn.

videoTitle: Running Tips From The World's Fastest Man | November 19, 2021
videoDescription: For the first time, the United States has recorded more than 100,000 drug overdose deaths in a 12-month period. What's being blamed for the worsening epidemic, and how have presidential administrations responded? That report is followed by an interview with Usain Bolt concerning his work with the Special Olympics. And we wrap up the week with a look at a "dog phone."

videoTitle: $1.2 Trillion Bill Sent To The President's Desk | November 8, 2021
videoDescription: The U.S. Congress has passed a $1.2 trillion infrastructure bill and sent it to President Biden's desk. Today's show tells you some of the initiatives in it and explains why it took several months to pass. We're also discussing jobs and the state of the American economy, and we're exploring why the U.S. "falls back" to standard time.

videoTitle: 20 Years Ago | September 10, 2021
videoDescription: This Friday, CNN 10 provides special coverage in advance of the 20th anniversary of the September 11 terrorist attacks. We're remembering what happened on that day in 2001 and how the events have been commemorated in subsequent years. And we're featuring the memories of an elementary school class that was with President George W. Bush when he was informed of the attacks.

videoTitle: Battle For The Arctic
videoDescription: CNN's Fred Pleitgen gets rare access to a Russian base in the North Pole as Russian President Vladimir Putin rapidly spreads the country's military presence around the Arctic.

videoTitle: An Above-Ground Pool....But For Real Though | May 4, 2021
videoDescription: A pair of proposals from President Joe Biden factor into today's first story on CNN 10. Then, we're watching a splash-down and discussing the recent work on the International Space Station. A proposal to capture carbon dioxide with kelp and a unique interpretation of an above-ground pool round out today's coverage.

videoTitle: An Address To Congress | April 29, 2021
videoDescription: What's been characterized as a U.S. political "super bowl" leads off today's show, as we cover some highlights of the president's annual message and the opposing party's response. Afterward, we're having some fun with a bit of trivia and a look at how live reporters have responded to animal photobombs.

videoTitle: History And Future Of Skyscrapers | April 26, 2021
videoDescription: Two days ahead of U.S. President Joe Biden's first "annual message" to Congress, we're exploring the history of similar speeches and explaining why they're not called "State of the Union" addresses. After that, we're taking to the skies for reports on the history and future of skyscrapers and the employment of drones in a light show over China.

videoTitle: Virtual Climate Summit | April 23, 2021
videoDescription: U.S. President Joe Biden kicks off a virtual climate summit with leaders from around the world. Researchers develop wearable technology that can be fastened to the skin. Turkish designers envision a floating hotel that generates its own electricity. And a superyacht is carefully moved through a narrow canal.

videoTitle: A History Of The First 100 Days
videoDescription: Looking back at the origin and tradition of a U.S. president's first 100 days in office.

videoTitle: The 100-Day Milestone | April 13, 2021
videoDescription: Our first topic this Tuesday: the history of the 100-day milestone for U.S. presidents. When did keeping track of this begin, and what does it look like in the modern era? That report is followed by a look back at the U.S. space shuttle program, almost exactly 40 years after it first lifted off. And a traffic signal for camels rates 10 out of 10.

videoTitle: A Hotel In Space | March 11, 2021
videoDescription: A surge of migrants at the border between the U.S. and Mexico puts pressure on agents and government officials. The anniversary of a pandemic declaration coincides with a U.S. presidential speech. And a future space hotel may offer guests with the means to stay without much of a weight.

videoTitle: The Science Of Wind Chill | February 12, 2021
videoDescription:
An ongoing standoff between the Indian government and the nation's farmers is the first event we're explaining today on CNN 10. Afterward, we're telling you why more cold weather is ahead for America, and we're detailing what exactly wind chill is. Finally, join us for a ride on a homemade bobsled track in Latvia!
CNN 10 will be off the air for the Presidents Day holiday and will look forward to seeing you again on Tuesday, February 16th.

videoTitle: An Impeachment Trial Begins | February 9, 2021
videoDescription: A former president's impeachment trial is set to get under way in the U.S. Senate on Tuesday. What are the major viewpoints on it, and how long is it expected to last? After that report, we update you on what's known about the new variants of coronavirus. And we take you to a small African country to understand why and how a conservationist is protecting grey crowned cranes.

videoTitle: The Science Of Snowflakes | February 5, 2021
videoDescription: Foreign policy headlines today's show, as President Biden outlines his administration's international agenda. A Nor'easter brings coastal flooding and massive amounts of snow to parts of the U.S. East Coast. The science of snowflakes and the advent of teqball are also featured this Friday on CNN 10.

videoTitle: The Debate Over Minimum Wage | January 28, 2021
videoDescription: Welcome to a new edition of CNN 10! Today's show explores the debate over minimum wage in America, the duties of the U.S. vice president, and the efforts to repopulate the "king of fish" in Maine. And if you've ever wondered how many tricks two dogs can do in a minute, Guinness World Records has your answer.

videoTitle: Recapping The Day | January 21, 2021
videoDescription: Today's special Inauguration Day coverage brings some sights and sounds of America's transition to its 46th president.  And we quiz you on the 20th Amendment!

videoTitle: Inauguration Day | January 20, 2021
videoDescription: A look at U.S. presidential inaugurations -- past and present -- is our first topic this Inauguration Day on CNN 10. Then, we're diving deep into a report about manta rays: Why are they threatened, and why do some conservations say they're easy to love? A rocket launched from an airplane and a new hotline that's a scream are today's other subjects.

videoDescription: One day away from the 2021 U.S. presidential inauguration, CNN 10 is giving you a glimpse of the security that's being prepared for the event. videoTitle: Explaining The Cabinet Of The United States
videoDescription: CNN's Kelly Mena takes a look at the function of the U.S. presidential Cabinet.

videoTitle: From Cabinets To Kelp | November 20, 2020

And then, a kelp farmer extolls the benefits of the growing industry. Finally, a wayward owl is freed from the Rockefeller Center Christmas tree.

videoTitle: Who Does President's Day Honor?

videoTitle: An Election Update | November 6, 2020
videoDescription: As vote counting continues in the United States, we're bringing you up to speed on what the two main presidential candidates said about victory yesterday. videoTitle: How Much Is An Asteroid Worth? | November 5, 2020
videoDescription: There are still a lot of unanswered questions about this week's U.S. presidential election, but today's show shares some new details with you concerning results. videoTitle: Is Halloween Canceled? | September 25, 2020
videoDescription: Presidential debates past and future are explored today on CNN 10. We're having a look at the impact of coronavirus on the airline industry. And we're detailing the CDC's new guidelines concerning Halloween. Finally, witness the rescue of a horse that took flight in California.

videoTitle: A Zombie Storm...Thanks 2020 | September 24, 2020
videoDescription: Exactly what is disinformation? The FBI is warning Americans about it ahead of the upcoming presidential election. Exactly what is a zombie storm? Meteorologists say one that made landfall in mid-September has strengthened again in the Atlantic. And exactly what is "hollerin"? The answer is in Spivey's Corner, North Carolina.

videoTitle: Talking Peace, Previewing Debates, And The World's Biggest Telescope | September 18, 2020
videoDescription: A historic agreement between three Middle Eastern countries has taken place at the White House, and today's show explains its significance. Finally, if you've ever wanted to own an authentic (and huge) dinosaur skeleton, we'll tell you how you can get one.

videoTitle: Time To Take Flight | September 8, 2020
videoDescription: Featured this Tuesday: A state of emergency has been declared in California amid historic wildfires. And we're taking a voyage into deep space with a pair of vehicles that are carrying sights and sounds of human life from the 1970s.

videoTitle: Drones Delivering To Your Home? | September 3, 2020
videoDescription: Facebook is accusing a Russian organization of attempting to sow discord ahead of the U.S. presidential election. American stocks are up, but the economy as a whole appears to be a mixed bag. Drones are helping keep tabs on illegal logging in the Amazon. And drones could be helping another Amazon make deliveries.

videoTitle: From City To City | September 2, 2020
videoDescription: Hong Kong, Moscow, and Beijing are three of our stops today as we have a look at how different cities are responding to continued coronavirus challenges. videoTitle: Football In Question...Movie Night? | August 13, 2020
videoDescription: Today's first topic brings you up to speed on the upcoming U.S. presidential election. After that, we're looking at where college football plans stand, as traditional kickoff dates approach. We also explain the early appearance of Halloween candy, and we examine how a haptic orchestra baton is a game changer for visually impaired musicians.

videoTitle: The Last Man On The Moon | August 4, 2020
videoDescription: With three months left until the U.S. presidential election, we're explaining everything you need to know about the election process.  We also look back at the last man on the moon and consider the future of space flight.  And finally, a project to rid Florida of invasive species scoops up 5000 pythons.

videoTitle: Anything But A Normal Year | July 29, 2020
videoDescription: New stimulus bills are being debated in the U.S. Congress, but will they reach the president's desk? New research indicates that the coronavirus has mutated, but is that necessarily bad news? And a new campus presents new opportunities for incoming college freshmen, but this is anything but a normal academic year.

videoTitle: How Presidential Cabinet Members Are Confirmed
videoDescription: CNN's Laura Jarrett explains what goes into the process (and history of) US Senate confirmations.  From nomination to confirmation, how the process works to become a presidential cabinet member.

videoTitle: Things That Come Up Often In Inaugural Speeches
videoDescription: No two presidents are ever the same, nor are their inaugural addresses. However, even though times have changed, many presidents have revisited the same topics.  Here's a look at how modern presidents have addressed the nation.

videoTitle: Is Putin The Most Powerful Man In The World?
videoDescription: Despite a floundering economy, Russia's president remains deeply popular at home. CNN's Matthew Chance reports.

videoTitle: New Normal: Education Goes Digital | March 19, 2020
videoDescription: An update on the U.S. presidential election process leads off today's show, and we take a closer look at what it means to earn delegates. We follow that up with a report on the impact of coronavirus and how it's changing the way many students are educated. And we're making a fly-by of Jupiter to get a closer view of the gas giant.

videoTitle: Carl Azuz Reacts To Memes | March 6, 2020
videoDescription: A NASA rover has sent back a highly detailed panorama of the Red Planet, so new images from Mars lead off today's show. From there, we're updating you the changing landscape of the U.S. presidential nomination process. And we're going to sea with a CNN Hero whose mission is to rehabilitate harbor seals and give them a second chance.

videoTitle: How To Become A Presidential Nominee | March 5, 2020
videoDescription: Results from Super Tuesday headline today's show, and we have a detailed explainer on exactly how delegates are chosen to represent a presidential candidate. Afterward, we explain why there's a state of emergency in the state of Tennessee. And we take you on a tour of what's said to be the "world's first department store."

videoTitle: Here Comes "Super" Tuesday | March 3, 2020
videoDescription: The nation of Israel is wrapping up its third round of elections in 11 months. Will they result in a coalition government? Also featured this Tuesday: an update on the U.S. presidential nomination process. And we're visiting with some of the rescuers (the human and canine kind) who help save lives in avalanche-prone areas.

videoTitle: "Retail Apocalypse" or "Retail Evolution" | March 2, 2020
videoDescription: The U.S. presidential nomination process yields several headlines, following Saturday's primary in South Carolina. We'll get you caught up on that, and we'll then explain why the term "retail apocalypse" may better be described as a "retail evolution." The ups and downs of vertical farming round out our first show of the week.

videoTitle: A New Ban On TikTok | February 27, 2020
videoDescription: U.S. President Donald Trump held a news conference last night to discuss coronavirus concerns in America, and today's show brings you some of the highlights. Afterward, we're explaining why the Transportation Security Administration is restricting its employees' use of TikTok. And a veterinarian provides free care for the pets of homeless Californian

videoTitle: The Relationship Between The U.S. And India | February 25, 2020
videoDescription: The important and complex relationship between the U.S. and India is examined today, as President Donald Trump wraps up his trip to the world's largest democracy. Afterward, we're taking you to the Canary Islands, which recently weathered a storm from the Sahara. We're also going dogsledding in British Columbia and checking in with a record-setting "plankster."

videoTitle: What Is "Super Tuesday"? | February 24, 2020
videoDescription: With high levels of flu activity being reported in 48 U.S. states, CNN 10 kicks off the week with a by-the-numbers look at flu season so far. That's followed by a recap of results from Saturday's Democratic caucuses in Nevada. And then, we're a featuring a look ahead to Super Tuesday and explaining why this date is so significant to U.S. presidential hopefuls.

videoTitle: A Controversial Facial Recognition Database | February 11, 2020
videoDescription: All eyes on New Hampshire: The second contest of the U.S. presidential nomination process takes place today. After a look at that and an update from Iowa, we're giving you an in-depth report on a controversial new startup that's amassed a database of faces. And we're showing you how a 1970s prank turned into a tradition at the University of Wisconsin..

videoTitle: The End Of President Trump's Impeachment Trial | February 6, 2020
videoDescription: The U.S. Senate acquittal of President Donald Trump is our first topic this Thursday. After a down-the-middle explanation of that, we're updating you on the status of the Wuhan coronavirus. And we're explaining how a type of "solar window" could change the way buildings are powered, though the technology has limitations.

videoTitle: Addressing The Nation | February 5, 2020
videoDescription: After we explore some history of the U.S. presidential State of the Union address, we're bringing you some highlights of President Donald Trump's fourth annual message to Congress. That's followed by some highlights of the Democratic Party's response. And we're also explaining what we know about complications with the Iowa caucuses.

videoTitle: Explaining The State Of The Union Address | February 4, 2020
videoDescription: Political headlines from the U.S. and abroad kick off today's show. The Iowa caucuses, the presidential State of the Union address, and the British exit from the European Union are our first three topics. We're also showing you a close-up of the sun's surface that was captured by a telescope in Hawaii.

videoTitle: A Plan For Peace In The Middle East | January 29, 2020
videoDescription: U.S. President Donald Trump unveils a plan for peace in the Middle East, and it receives both praise and criticism. A report that comes along once in a blue moon follows. And while supporters say smart factories are the manufacturing hubs of the future, they come with some significant downsides.

videoTitle: How Does A Caucus Work? | January 27, 2020
videoDescription: One week away from the Iowa caucuses, CNN 10 is updating you on the status of the U.S. presidential race and explaining how caucuses work. After that, we're reporting on the untimely death of a U.S. basketball champion. And as football fans gear up for the Super Bowl, we're examining what companies pay to advertise and why they're willing to do it.

videoTitle: U.S. Senate Begins Impeachment Trial | January 21, 2020
videoDescription: The U.S. Senate has opened an impeachment trial for President Donald Trump. A mysterious virus has surfaced in China, and health officials worldwide are on guard. New studies support the idea of less screen time and more reading time for young children. And a candy company constructs a colossal, caloric confection.

videoTitle: Debates Over Border Security | January 10, 2019
videoDescription: Today's show brings you highlights of a U.S. presidential address and opposing party's response, as debates heat up over border security and a partial government shutdown. On the heels of a North Korean leader's surprise trip to China, we're examining the relationship between the two countries. And smart technology is taking over parks in the United Arab Emirates.

videoTitle: Presidential Visit To The Border | January 11, 2019
videoDescription: A presidential visit to a U.S. border town, a look at a new type of technology being tested at U.S. airports, and a trek through the desert in Dubai are our main topics this Friday. We'll also test your knowledge of Greek mythology and the origin of the modern marathon.

videoTitle: State Of The Union Called Off | January 25, 2019
videoDescription: The U.S. president's annual State of the Union speech has been called off for now. Find out what led to its postponement -- and what the Constitution has to say about the address. Today's show also covers the world's largest annual human migration. And we look at an attempt to reduce plastic waste by reviving a milkman delivery model.

videoTitle: Historic Rains Open Up A Dam | February 5, 2019
videoDescription: Australia is the site of today's first report, as we bring you an explanation of why a dam was opened amid historic rains and how a city downstream was flooded. The deployment of 3,750 more U.S. troops to America's southern border makes headlines ahead of President Trump's upcoming State of the Union Address. And we consider what the televisions of the future will look like.

videoTitle: History Of The State Of The Union Address | February 6, 2019
videoDescription: Today's show describes some of the history and traditions associated with the U.S. president's State of the Union address and the opposing party's response. You'll hear from President Donald Trump, a Republican, and Stacey Abrams, a Democrat and former gubernatorial nominee. Afterward, we take a look at some of the traditions associated with a major holiday in China.

videoTitle: Political Stability in Haiti | February 19, 2019
videoDescription: The Caribbean nation of Haiti is our first stop today, where protests and corruption threaten the political stability of the country. Then, we're taking you to Venezuela, where there's a standoff between the government and the opposition concerning the delivery of aid. After that, we're explaining how the Presidents Day holiday got its start. And we conclude with a treetop visit to the jungle of Laos.

videoTitle: India's Election That Lasts More Than A Month | April 12, 2019
videoDescription: Following a military coup in the African country of Sudan, we're examining the turbulent tenure of former President Omar al-Bashir. And we're showing you how an e-commerce company is utilizing drones to make deliveries in Australia.

videoTitle: The History of Notre Dame Cathedral | April 17, 2019
videoDescription: This Wednesday, the history of Notre Dame Cathedral and the experience of running for U.S. president are our first two subjects. We're recapping a recent SpaceX venture, and we're showing you what lightning looks like when it hits the top of the world's tallest building.

videoTitle: New Law Requiring Students To Take The U.S. Naturalization Test | May 2, 2019
videoDescription: With the 2020 U.S. presidential election just over a year and a half away, we're explaining why candidacies are announced so early. And we're examining some varied applications for forthcoming 5G wireless technology.

videoTitle: Race For The White House | November 4, 2020
videoDescription: This Wednesday's show takes a limited look at news concerning the U.S. presidential election, based on what was known late last night. videoTitle: One Week Till Election Day | October 27, 2020
videoDescription: With one week to go until Election Day, we're providing some perspective from the 2016 presidential election concerning both polling and early voting. And we're taking flight with a pair of space stories before parachuting back down to Earth.

videoTitle: A Look At The Final Debate | October 23, 2020
videoDescription: Today's show begins with a short recap of Thursday night's second and final U.S. presidential debate. videoTitle: New Rule For The Presidential Debate | October 22 2020
videoDescription: Flooding in Vietnam headlines today's show, as an unusually heavy rainy season claims lives and homes. Then, with plastic continuing to proliferate in the environment, we're looking into one company's proposed solution.

videoTitle: 9 Million Have Already Voted | October 13, 2020
videoDescription: Today's show begins by bringing you up to speed on coronavirus headlines from several countries. videoTitle: Hearings, Debates, And Landfall | October 12, 2020

videoTitle: Blue Moon Rising On Halloween | October 9, 2020
videoDescription: A state of emergency in the state of Louisiana is our first subject this Friday, as Hurricane Delta approaches. And some uninvited, furry White House residents make their presence known to reporters.

videoTitle: NFL Using Video Surveillance | October 8, 2020
videoDescription: Just what are a vice presidential candidate's goals going into a debate? The monetary challenges facing the U.S. Postal Service are another subject we cover. And we explain how the NFL is turning to video surveillance to enforce its rules concerning coronavirus.

videoTitle: What Doctors, Observers, And The President Himself Are Saying | October 5, 2020
videoDescription: When today's show was produced, U.S. President Donald Trump was in the hospital fighting coronavirus. Afterward, we blast off with a pair of space stories.

videoTitle: It Was Debate Night | September 30, 2020
videoDescription: On Tuesday night, incumbent Republican President Donald Trump and Democratic Presidential Nominee Joe Biden met for their first debate. videoTitle: Let The Debate Begin | September 29, 2020
