From there, we're taking you out West for an update on the wildfires burning there. And off the U.S. East Coast, a puffin project brings birds back to a small island.

videoTitle: Tech and the Healthcare Industry | November 13, 2019
videoDescription: An overview of a deteriorating situation in eastern Asia. A down-the-middle look at what to expect in the ongoing impeachment investigation involving the House of Representatives and the U.S. president. An explanation of a controversial project between a technology company and a healthcare organization. All of this and more is featured today on CNN 10!

videoTitle: The Bubonic Plague Still a Threat? | November 25, 2019
videoDescription: A trade deal between the U.S. and China could be reached before the year is over, but American companies that do business overseas are still subject to political challenges. Meanwhile, a devastating disease described in history books still poses a threat today. And the board game of Life may owe its popularity to a former president's beard.

videoTitle: The Functions of the United Nations | September 25, 2019
videoDescription: After a brief overview of a fast-moving story involving the U.S. president and the House of Representatives, we're taking you inside the United Nations to explain the functions of the international organization. An eerie, red haze flares up in Indonesia, and a researcher uses MRI technology to learn what dogs may be thinking.

videoTitle: Examining the Whistleblower Compliant | September 27, 2019
videoDescription: A day after we explained a phone call at the center of a controversy involving President Trump, we're looking into the whistleblower complaint concerning the call. Afterward, we're taking a historic look at the impeachment process and examining what the U.S. Constitution says about it. Our other stories explore what it's like to work on an offshore wind farm and where you can experience the world's longest water slide.

videoTitle: The Cost of Running for President | October 15, 2019
videoDescription: Today's show begins by updating you on recent events in Syria and explaining how other countries factor in. Then, we're examining the complicated and expensive process of running for U.S. president. And we're showing you how a company is helping concrete producers cut down on carbon dioxide emissions.

videoTitle: The End of NAFTA | December 11, 2019
videoDescription: Two U.S. political events concerning the House of Representatives and President Donald Trump headline today's show. They're followed by a look at underground farming in South Korea. And from there, we're speaking to NASA's administrator about the costs and plans of future space missions.

videoTitle: How the Impeachment Process Works | December 3, 2019
videoDescription: An objective explanation of the ongoing U.S. impeachment investigation concerning the House of Representatives and President Donald Trump. It's followed by a nuclear challenge facing Germany. And if the advent of edible bowls doesn't make you hungry, a ride in a banana car may sound appealing.

videoTitle: Big Test Ahead | April 6, 2020
videoDescription: As the Trump Administration warns of a big test in the coming days, there are hopeful signs out of Italy concerning the coronavirus pandemic. A technology company illustrates how cell phones can be tracked across America and beyond. And a trip to northern Japan reveals a beautiful landscape for those who love winter.

videoTitle: This new technology can power thousands of homes
videoDescription: Several companies are developing technologies to harness the largely untapped renewable energy our oceans can provide.

videoTitle: American Cars Reach A New Record
videoDescription: As China's zero-Covid policy takes a toll on its economy, we're following a CNN reporter through Beijing to see what life is like under restrictions in the capital. The average age of American cars reaches a record, as people drive them longer than ever. A Boeing spacecraft makes an overall successful flight after a string of setbacks. And a "sharkcano" erupts in the Pacific.

videoTitle: A Total Lunar Eclipse
videoDescription: A shooting at a supermarket in Buffalo, New York appears to be a hate crime. Market analysts say the future of a popular cryptocurrency could be either very bright or very dim. A "super flower blood moon" is visible in many countries during a total lunar eclipse. And the partial skeleton of a velociraptor hits the auction block.

videoTitle: Where Is The Formula?
videoDescription: We're reporting on jobs, shortages and cave art. Our first story centers on the latest U.S. jobs and unemployment report and how it's a bright spot in an otherwise-mixed economic picture. Then, we're taking a look at a nationwide shortage of baby formula and how it's impacting families with newborns. And we're explaining how researchers discovered nearly invisible cave art -- and why they're not saying exactly where it is.

videoTitle: A Look At The Supreme Court
videoDescription: This Friday's show begins with a trio of headlines: One concerns an island-wide power outage in Puerto Rico; one reports on the confirmation of a new U.S. Supreme Court justice; and one involves new penalties against the nation of Russia. An explanation of potential war crimes follows. And we're reporting on the opening of the world's skinniest skyscraper.

videoTitle: Explaining Tornadoes
videoDescription: We're featuring a pair of reports on natural disasters. First, we take you to the U.S. state with the highest number of active wildfires to examine how much territory they've burned -- and what could happen if they're not brought under control. Then, we're discussing tornado damage and other problems caused by a storm system that has swept the southern U.S. Also: Could a robotic "manicurist" threaten jobs held by humans?

videoTitle: To Tip Or Not To Tip?
videoDescription: How have Americans' tipping habits changed throughout the Covid pandemic, and how might that fit into a broader economic picture? That's today's first topic, and it's followed by a trip to New Zealand's South Island, where endangered sea lions may be staging a comeback. Also: A snowman mysteriously appears in South Dakota's 60-degree weather.

videoTitle: A Warning For The Economy?
videoDescription: The U.S. economy surprisingly contracted at a pace of 1.4 percent in the first quarter of this year. The significance of that -- and the silver lining to the report -- are our first topics on today's show. A historic drought in the American West takes its toll on several states, and an Illinois home renovation reveals a classic combo.

videoTitle: Midterm Moods
videoDescription: A preview of the upcoming U.S. Midterm Elections -- along with what some Democrats and Republicans are saying -- is front and center today on CNN 10. We're discussing what's known about natural immunity with regard to Covid-19. And we're telling you where a couple alligators have been strolling through the neighborhood.

videoTitle: A Mask Mandate Change
videoDescription: A federal judge overturns the U.S. government's extended mask mandate for public transportation. Another U.S. weapons package is sent to Ukraine, as Russia signals a change in tactics. And a family in Wisconsin devises a unique and colorful way to tell their triplets apart.

videoTitle: Is Amazon A Monopoly?
videoDescription: Today’s special edition of CNN 10 focuses on Amazon, the $1.5 trillion U.S. company that has changed the retail landscape. We’ll explore some of the technology it uses, the challenges it has faced and created, the concerns about whether it’s a monopoly, and the profits it has generated.

videoTitle: What Is E15 Gasoline?
videoDescription: The Biden administration is lifting a summertime ban on E15 gasoline: What is it, and will the action have an impact on soaring gas prices? After that report, we're examining what it's like to live in Shanghai, China during a highly restrictive lockdown. And we're explaining why new information concerning Neptune has scientists scratching their heads.

videoTitle: A New Moon Mission
videoDescription: U.S. inflation rates continue their highest rise in decades. Today's show covers figures from March and explains why even a peak won't signal a rapid return to normalcy. Other topics featured today include increased transit security, another step in a new moon mission, and a driverless car that broke the law.

videoTitle: A New Infrastructure Plan | April 1, 2021
videoDescription: The Biden Administration has released a new infrastructure plan. What's in it, and why is congressional debate expected to take months? Meantime, facial recognition technology sees greater use in crowded places, and it brings both convenience and concerns about privacy violations. And a mama bear exemplifies the challenges of parenting when ferrying her cubs across a road.

videoTitle: It's March | March 1, 2021
videoDescription: The Biden Administration's proposed stimulus package advances in the U.S. Congress but may face some changes before it becomes law. Experts discuss the possible psychological impacts of the Covid pandemic on young people. A drone helps keep tabs on an endangered dolphin subspecies in New Zealand. And a common dolphin species "stampedes" off the coast of California.

videoTitle: Scientists confirm 'God Particle' exists 10 years ago. Watch CNN's coverage of the discovery
videoDescription: The Large Hadron Collider will restart again as scientists at the the European Organization for Nuclear Research search for a better understanding of the building blocks of the universe. Ten years ago, the machine helped scientists confirm the existence of the Higgs boson. Watch CNN's coverage in 2012 of this groundbreaking discovery.

videoTitle: Graphic shows all the changes in global temperature since 1850
videoDescription: Heat waves are becoming more intense because of the rise in global temperature, which has devastating effects on landscapes, ecosystems and even the human body. Climate experts explain why this matters and what can be done to stabilize the planet's temperature.

videoTitle: How NATO will change when Finland and Sweden join the alliance
videoDescription: The North Atlantic Treaty Organisation was initially founded to protect Western European countries from the threat posed by the Soviet Union. Over seven decades later, as Russia's war in Ukraine continues, NATO's role in the region has come back into focus.

videoTitle: The Science Of Sleep
videoDescription: An update on the war in Ukraine, including a firsthand look at its impact on a Ukrainian community, is our first report today. Afterward, we're examining the science of sleep, from tips for getting better rest to devices that aim to closely track sleep quality. And when an eaglet accidentally falls from its nest, wildlife officials swoop in to help.

videoTitle: What Is A No Fly Zone?
videoDescription: Today's show explores the complex and connected factors in the rising costs of housing. We're also reporting on something Ukraine wants but that the U.S. refuses to provide. And we're telling the tale of Steve, a wayward owl whom police removed from a stranger's home.

videoTitle: Is Going To Mars A Good Idea?
videoDescription: Are steps being taken that could lead to peace in Ukraine? That's our first topic today, and it's followed by a look at a large-scale lockdown in Shanghai, China. A potential mission of humans to colonize Mars is our next subject. And we round out the show with a bit of "robot art."

videoTitle: Searching For Snow Leopards
videoDescription: NATO leaders announce new initiatives concerning the war in Ukraine, but the fighting rages on. A conservationist works in Pakistan to help farmers whose livestock has been attacked by a vulnerable species of cat. And a couple in New Zealand finds out their record-sized spud isn't quite a spud after all.

videoTitle: The Supreme Court Confirmation Process
videoDescription: Another step is taken in the U.S. Supreme Court confirmation process. Dozens of wildfires scorch thousands of acres in Texas. Aid from around the world pours into the war-torn nation of Ukraine. And a naming competition is announced after the birth of a baby eaglet.

videoTitle: Delivering Cars Without All The Parts?
videoDescription: Experts on international affairs are concerned that China may be observing events in Ukraine and considering its own invasion of Taiwan. Amid shortages of semiconductors, some U.S. carmakers are delivering vehicles without certain features. And we're providing a bit of art education today with a primer on landscape art and an interview with a modern impressionist.

videoTitle: Where Will The Space Station Splash Down?
videoDescription: Government officials representing Ukraine and Russia are holding regular meetings, but none has resulted in a ceasefire. As NASA prepares to decommission the ISS, we’re explaining how researchers are documenting day-to-day life in the orbiter. And a U.S. pharmacy chain tests out “cooler screens,” but some consumers are not impressed.

videoTitle: Large Spiders In The Southeast
videoDescription: Thousands of people flee war-torn areas of Ukraine. South Korea elects a new leader. Hawaii becomes the last U.S. state to drop its mask mandate. Large spiders proliferate in the American Southeast. And sheep take over Paris' famous Champs-Élysées for a one-kilometer stroll.

videoTitle: A Remarkable Shipwreck Is Found
videoDescription: In today's show, a CNN reporter in Ukraine shows you what it's like for civilians to evacuate their war-torn city. In the state of Iowa, an emergency declaration speeds up aid to those whose homes were damaged by a tornado. And the discovery of a remarkably well-preserved shipwreck makes headlines from Lake Superior.

videoTitle: Why Geography Matters To Russia
videoDescription: We're breaking out the maps in today's show to help illustrate the tensions between NATO and Russia over Ukraine. Afterward, we're speaking with the man who predicted a collision between a Chinese rocket stage and the moon. And a gymnast sets a giant high bar when it comes to high-bar giants.

videoTitle: Russia Invades Ukraine
videoDescription: Following Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, today's show gives an overview of what's happening there and how international leaders are responding. Our other topics include efforts to "rewild" part of Portugal and the return of a long-lost dog to its owner.

videoTitle: U.S. and Russian Forces On The Move
videoDescription: U.S. and Russian officials are giving very different indications about a potential Russian invasion of Ukraine. See how both of these nations are moving their troops around in the region. We're also headed out to sea to follow the path of a student-launched mini-boat that was lost and found again.

videoTitle: Weather And War
videoDescription: How might the weather impact a possible Russian invasion of Ukraine? That forecast is first today on CNN 10. Female athletes at the 2022 Winter Olympics have set a number of records; when did women first compete in the Olympic Games? And speaking of records, a man who's made a career of setting new ones completes a major feat.

videoTitle: The Mood Near The Border
videoDescription:
The United States is deploying 3,000 troops across three European countries, and today's show explains why and what the mood is like near Ukraine's eastern border with Russia. Afterward, we're reporting on a record number of job resignations in America, and we're taking you to a very remote part of the world where the International Space Station is likely to come down in the years ahead.

Chapters:

videoTitle: Lessons From Space | January 25, 2022
videoDescription: A violent crime wave rises in U.S. cities from coast to coast. The U.S. tells non-essential personnel to leave its embassy in Ukraine. A European astronaut discusses how some lessons learned on the International Space Station could be applied on Earth. And a photographer captures "ice pancakes" on Lake Michigan.

videoTitle: Two Sleeps A Day? | January 11, 2022
videoDescription: U.S. and Russian officials are holding a series of meetings to discuss the situation in Ukraine; why is this nation important to both sides? Meantime, as different countries take vastly different approaches in responding to Covid, some people get stuck even after following the rules. A new study explores a historic European practice of "first sleep" and "second sleep." And researchers consider whether dogs can become bilingual.

videoTitle: A High-Stakes Call | December 9, 2021
videoDescription: A high-stakes call between the leaders of the United States and Russia centers on a tense situation in Ukraine. As giant pandas have made a comeback, China is taking steps to conserve them by expanding protected areas. And two "speed skydivers" achieve world records by aiming straight down.

videoTitle: How an act of kindness became a world record
videoDescription: Texas resident Chris Penny found a couple of painted rocks on the trail and decided to make the Parr Park in his city of Grapevine a Guinness record destination for people from around the world.

videoTitle: A Look At Lithium Mining
videoDescription: Lockdowns in China are having ripple effects on supplies of goods around the world. A part of California described as an "economic and environmental wasteland" could harbor enough lithium to power America's electric car industry, but mining the metal can have a negative environmental impact. And a startup company aims to revolutionize rocket launches by using a "flinging" method.

videoTitle: A Software Security Flaw | December 15, 2021
videoDescription:
Welcome to our last show of 2021! A security flaw in widely used computer software has sent engineers scrambling to implement a fix. A biologist in South Africa is using his camera to raise awareness about the importance of freshwater. A young pilot makes progress on her quest to set a world record. And a family breaks its own world record for Christmas lights.
Thank you for being the best part of CNN 10! We look forward to seeing you again in early January.

videoTitle: A Very Unique Ski Slope | December 13, 2021
videoDescription: Today's show begins with a report on the destruction caused by dozens of suspected tornadoes that struck eight U.S. states over the weekend. After our daily trivia question, we're headed to Denmark to report on the pros and cons of a unique waste treatment plant that doubles as a ski slope. And we're visiting a home in Germany that holds the world record for having the most decorated Christmas trees.

videoTitle: An Olympic Boycott | December 8, 2021
videoDescription: The U.S. has announced a diplomatic boycott of the upcoming Winter Olympics. What does that mean, and how has China responded? We're remembering the Japanese attack on the U.S. naval base in Pearl Harbor, 80 years after the event took place. And we're visiting the world's highest continent for a rare glimpse of a total solar eclipse.

videoTitle: Crashing Into Asteroids | November 22, 2021
videoDescription: The future of California's giant sequoias -- and the challenges facing them -- are our first subjects this Monday. That report is followed by an explanation of a mission to crash a spacecraft into an asteroid's "moonlet." Finally, we're reporting on an auction record set by a printing of the world's oldest governing document.

videoTitle: New Technology And Sports | November 12, 2021
videoDescription: A look at Veterans Day events -- from the U.S. and beyond -- is the focus of our first report this Friday. From there, we're looking at how new technology can provide extensive statistical data about organized sports. And we're showing you how a centenarian just set a world record on the track.

videoTitle: Predictor Of Future Votes? | November 2, 2021
videoDescription: Leaders from around the world gather in Glasgow, Scotland for a United Nations climate summit. How will they balance the call to lower emissions with the demand for non-renewable energy? The U.S. political spotlight shines on two gubernatorial races that are seen as bellwethers for future votes. And we show you the list of the top 10 CNN Heroes of 2021.

videoTitle: How Deep Is The Ocean? | November 1, 2021
videoDescription: How deep is the ocean? Today's special edition of CNN 10 takes you to the deepest part of the world's deepest trench in the world's deepest ocean. You'll meet a man who recently went there, and you'll hear his views on the importance of exploring the deep blue sea.

videoTitle: Travel Rules Changing | October 18, 2021
videoDescription: The U.S. government has set a date for when its rules change regarding international travel. A CNN Hero sets up a barter system to address two problems on the Indonesian island of Bali. And a golden retriever scoops up a number of tennis balls and fetches a new world record.

videoTitle: Knowing The Origins Of Covid-19 | October 14, 2021
videoDescription: Depending on transparency from China, the world may be one step closer to knowing the origins of Covid-19. Depending on the industry, the U.S. workforce took a major hit in August. And depending on perseverance and determination, a young athlete sets a record by competing in an Ironman Triathlon.

videoTitle: A Close Eye On The U.S. Congress | September 28, 2021
videoDescription: Today's show explains why political analysts are keeping a close eye on the U.S. Congress this week, as lawmakers grapple over various bills worth trillions. A fuel crisis in the United Kingdom leaves thousands of gas stations with empty pumps. An effort is underway to protect the whales in one of the world's busiest waterways. And a little dog sets a big record in baseball.

videoTitle: New Travel Rules - Who Can? | September 23, 2021
videoDescription: The U.S. government has announced new rules for international airline travel, and we're giving you an overview of them in today's show. For an estimated 90 percent of the world's population, fall has begun, and we're exploring the reasons why leaves change colors. And a 19-year-old flyer is hoping to become the youngest woman ever to make a solo flight around the world.

videoTitle: No Microchips And A Dino Discovery | September 8, 2021
videoDescription: In the aftermath of Hurricane Ida, some residents of the Gulf Coast are grappling with a tough decision: Do they stay and rebuild or look to live somewhere else? Meanwhile, a worsening shortage of microchips is forcing shutdowns among some carmakers. Scientists say a massive "dino discovery" has been made in Australia. And a pilot sets a new Guinness world record.

videoTitle: Daily Life, Economics, And A Very Fast Build | September 7, 2021
videoDescription: Daily life under the Taliban is our first topic this Tuesday, as there is conflicting information about what the Afghan group is saying versus what it's doing. The U.S. economy added 235,000 new jobs last month, and we're explaining why that's considered a disappointment and what is being blamed for it. And a Chinese company claims the "world's shortest construction period" for an apartment building, but there's a caveat.

videoTitle: Chaos In Afghanistan | August 24, 2021
videoDescription: Our second show of the season begins with a down-the-middle explanation of the chaos in Afghanistan. It's followed by a report on recent natural disasters in Haiti and a look at why it's so hard to get help to some in need. And we're reporting on a 100-year-old World War II veteran who just made another jump from a vintage plane.

videoTitle: Exploring The Deepest Part Of The Ocean
videoDescription: We're taking you to the deepest point of the deepest trench in the world's deepest ocean. And we're talking to an adventurer about what it's like to go there, how long it takes to dive there, and why it's scientifically important to explore this frontier

videoTitle: The Deepest Point Of The Deepest Trench In The Deepest Ocean...That's Deep | May 21, 2021
videoDescription: We have an in-depth special edition this Friday! We're taking you to the deepest point of the deepest trench in the world's deepest ocean. And we're talking to an adventurer about what it's like to go there, how long it takes to dive there, and why it's scientifically important to explore this frontier.

videoTitle: Pros And Cons Of Electric Cars | May 12, 2021
videoDescription: Americans between the ages of 12 and 15 are now eligible for a Covid-19 vaccine, and the responses from parents are mixed. The world's most populous nation is seeing a concerning decline in birth rate. Archaeologists make a fascinating (and somewhat troubling) discovery in Italy. And we explore some of the pros and cons of electric cars.

videoTitle: An Out Of Control Rocket | May 6, 2021
videoDescription: U.S. troops begin their withdrawal from Afghanistan, but observers are voicing concerns about the future of the nation's women and girls. A Chinese rocket is headed back down to Earth, but it's out of control: Should people be worried? Broadway is getting the green light to reopen, but it'll be months before the first show is live. And an American woman breaks a world record for running a 50K.

videoTitle: Genetically Modified Mosquitoes | May 3, 2021
videoDescription: As India confronts a record-setting number of new Covid cases, other nations send aid to the world's largest democracy. As cases decline in America, more venues open to crowds. As genetically modified mosquitoes are released in the Florida Keys, an environmental group cries foul. And amid the challenges of today's education environment, a CNN Hero pivots to help kids in Chicago.

videoTitle: Exploring The World's Deepest Shipwreck
videoDescription: The world's deepest known shipwreck, a World War II US Navy destroyer, has been fully mapped and filmed by a US-based crew. CNN's Ivan Watson reports.

videoTitle: Explaining NFTs
videoDescription: CNN's Jon Sarlin talks with Carlos Marcial and Osinachi, two of the many digital artists around the world who have seen their lives turned upside down with the booming market for NFTs —the digital tokens that have fueled the rise of an unprecedented market for digital art.

videoTitle: An Explanation Of NFTs | April 8, 2021
videoDescription: Two years after Facebook was hacked, the personal information of roughly 530 million accounts has appeared on a hacker website. The details on this story lead off today's show. That's followed by an explanation of non-fungible tokens and how they may reshape the digital art world. And a swarm of bees in a grocery shopper's car leads to a call for help in New Mexico.

videoTitle: World's Deepest Shipwreck | April 7, 2021
videoDescription: After obtaining permission from the Burmese military to report from inside Myanmar, a CNN reporter conducts interviews in the southeast Asian country. videoTitle: Origins Of The Virus | March 31, 2021
videoDescription: The World Health Organization has released a new report on the origins of coronavirus, but there are still a lot of unanswered questions. The container ship that blocked the Suez Canal has been freed, but the accident could have a lasting impact on the shipping industry. And a new jet could take passengers around the world in record time, but it needs to get off the ground first.

videoTitle: An International Update | March 16, 2021
videoDescription: A report on the ongoing unrest in Myanmar headlines today's show. It's followed by a look at coronavirus-related headlines from around the world. Then, we update you on the surge of migrants at the border between Mexico and the U.S. And we give you a view of smart glass that could change windows as we know them.

videoTitle: Flightless Parrot Making a Comeback
videoDescription: The kakapo is the world's only flightless parrot -- and it's in trouble. But conservationists in New Zealand are trying to bring it back from the brink.

videoTitle: A City-Sized Iceberg | March 2, 2021
videoDescription: Protests in Myanmar and Hong Kong headline today's show, as we explore tensions between civilians and government forces. From there, we're taking you to Antarctica for a look at the calving of a massive glacier. Then, we're headed out to sea to explore the challenges and beauty a young rower saw while setting a new world record.

videoTitle: The Business Of Podcasts
videoDescription: Spotify is one of the biggest music streaming platforms in the world. CNN Business' Rachel Crane sits down with Chief Content Officer Dawn Ostroff to find out why the company wants to be your podcast home.

videoTitle: Kites Used To Gather Energy
videoDescription:
One company’s self-flying energy kite may be the answer to increasing wind power around the world.

California-based Makani – which is owned by Google’s parent company, Alphabet – is using power from the strongest winds found out in the middle of the ocean, typically in spots where it’s a challenge to install traditional wind turbines. Makani hopes to create electricity to power communities across the world.

videoTitle: What Is The Nobel Prize?
videoDescription: The Nobel Prize grants entry into one of the most prestigious clubs in the world. Here's what you need to know about one of the most sought after accolades.

videoTitle: Life Aboard An Ocean Windmill
videoDescription: The world’s largest offshore wind farm is taking shape off the east coast of Britain, a landmark project that demonstrates one way to combat climate change at scale.

videoTitle: How To Build The World's Biggest Offshore Wind Farm
videoDescription: Britain's east coast will soon house the world's largest offshore wind farm in a major step forward for renewable energy generation.

videoTitle: World's Busiest Crosswalk
videoDescription: You're looking at Shibuya Crossing - often referred to as the world's busiest crosswalk.  CNN's Chris James reports...

videoTitle: An Impeachment Vote | January 14, 2021
videoDescription: An impeachment vote in the U.S. House of Representatives -- and some of the history of this process -- is today's first topic. Then, we're reporting on a new restriction concerning airline travel to the U.S. A lava "meatball," the world's busiest intersection, and an icy winter wonderland round out our show!

videoTitle: A Remote Island Where People Live Longer?
videoDescription: A visit to the remote Greek island of Ikaria where inhabitants live longer than most Americans and try to maintain their centuries old way of life in a modern world.

videoTitle: The World's Biggest Economy | January 12, 2021
videoDescription: The world's biggest economy leads off today's show, as we look at the current U.S. jobs situation and outlook for the months ahead. Then, we're explaining the background of the 25th Amendment and the current debate surrounding it. And finally, an organization volunteers to help transport future service dogs to trainers around the country.

videoTitle: Robots Find A New Job? - Skyscraper Window Washers
videoDescription:
A skyscraper window washer regularly ranks among the toughest jobs in the world.

The role, which can pay an upward of $27 an hour, often requires workers to hang hundreds of feet above the ground. The high wages and steep turnover rates have made the industry ripe for automation.

videoTitle: The Pros And Cons Of Contact Tracing | December 17, 2020
videoDescription: The pros and cons of contact tracing -- and its application in South Korea -- are our first topics today on CNN 10. China has just completed a mission to retrieve rocks from the moon, and we're explaining why the country sees that as more than a technological achievement. And we're taking a drive on a historic German highway that inspired road networks around the world.

videoTitle: A Planet Where It Rains Rocks | December 4, 2020
videoDescription: There are a lot of ups and downs on CNN 10 today. An unmanned mission to the moon and an outline of a newly discovered exoplanet headline the show. We're discussing the pros and cons of vertical farming, and we're diving into the world's deepest swimming pool. And finally, a tumbleweed snowman brings a little Christmas spirit to the desert.

videoTitle: Black Friday Shopping 2020 | November 13, 2020
videoDescription: Developing a vaccine is one challenge; distributing it is another. Today's show starts with a look at the logistics involved in sending a shot around the world. Also featured: at look at the potential impact of the coronavirus pandemic on Black Friday shopping. And before we leave for the weekend, we're taking a swim with a robotic dolphin.

videoTitle: What's It Like To Stay In An Ice Hotel?
videoDescription:
It's been 30 years since the world's first hotel made of snow and ice launched, and the team behind Sweden's ICEHOTEL have gone all out to mark the occasion.

A frosty theater production, an ice-carved observation deck and a frozen feline lair are among the new designs on display as the iconic hotel opens for its new winter season.

videoTitle: What Was It Like To Fly During The First World War?
videoDescription: It's been 100 years since World War I, when airplanes like these changed warfare forever. Today, pilots still fly vintage WWI beauties at Old Rhinebeck Aerodrome in New York.

videoTitle: Insects That Eat Plastic? | October 7, 2020
videoDescription: There's a lot of science on CNN 10 this Wednesday. We're reporting on weather in the Caribbean, tides and flood barriers in Italy, and plastic in the ocean. And we're examining whether mealworms could potentially become a solution to the world's plastic waste.

videoTitle: The First Tall Building In The Desert
videoDescription: In 1979, the tallest building between Mumbai and Greece was built in Dubai's desert. The city's first skyscraper came to symbolize its ambitions on the world stage.

videoTitle: Leaders Go Online and Fall Arrives | September 23, 2020
videoDescription: In a first for the United Nations, its General Assembly is meeting online. Will this impact the effectiveness of the annual event? We're also looking at the logistics of distributing a potential coronavirus vaccine worldwide. And we're providing some fun facts about fall, which officially started Tuesday. Finally, get roped into a report on tug-of-war.

videoTitle: See The Antarctic From A Whale's-Eye View
videoDescription: Scientists in Antarctica have attached a camera to a minke whale in what they say is a world first.

videoTitle: Robots Versus Virus | August 18, 2020
videoDescription: New Zealand, Japan, and the South China Sea are three of our stops on today's global edition of CNN 10! We're also discussing the possible use of ultraviolet light in preventing the spread of Covid-19. And we're celebrating the birthday of a panda who's believed to be the oldest in the world.

videoTitle: How To Build An Indoor Rainforest
videoDescription: From pit to paradise, the UK's Eden Project is making a name for itself by creating rainforests in cities across the world.

videoTitle: What Is The Ring Of Fire?
videoDescription: This line of tectonic plates stretches across the globe, producing 90% of the world's earthquakes.

videoTitle: A Look At World War II Code Breaking | August 6, 2020
videoDescription: A massive explosion has sent the nation of Lebanon to a day of mourning.  With most students in Bolivia without access to online learning, the country has canceled school for the year.  And we take a look back at a World War II code breaking effort and speak with a woman who was a part of the secret mission.

videoTitle: Pandemic Shifting Where People Live? | August 5, 2020
videoDescription: With the pandemic shifting the way people work, learn, and live....are people still flocking to the cities?  And with more and more Major League Baseball games being postponed, what's the outlook for the World Series?  And finally we dive under the sea to visit an underwater museum on today's episode of CNN 10.

videoTitle: Sports Are Coming Back | July 28, 2020
videoDescription: Sports are slowly starting up again around the world, but the stadiums are still largely silent, and there are still concerns about the spread of Covid-19. There are signs that a generation that once shunned the suburbs is starting to move there. And there's a mechanized band of scrap metal and air pressure pistons that's drawing crowds around the world.

videoTitle: Inside The Orion Rocket
videoDescription: See where the most powerful rocket in the world is being built, and step inside the advanced spacecraft that could take humans farther than ever before.

videoTitle: Perspectives On Closures | June 16, 2020
videoDescription: After some very different perspectives of coronavirus closures and the U.S. economy, we're traveling around the world today for a snapshot at where other countries are in their responses to the disease. After that, we check in on the status of pro sports plans, and we show you how youth sports are coping with the challenges brought on by a pandemic.

videoTitle: How To Get Paid For Building Legos
videoDescription: Duncan Titmarsh is the UK's only certified professional LEGO builder, creating World Records using hundreds of thousands of bricks.

videoTitle: What Is Snow Kiting?
videoDescription: The Red Bull Ragnorak in Haugastol, Norway is not only the world's largest snowkiting race, it's the toughest. Only about 7% of the racers finish each year.

videoTitle: The Role Of Antibodies | May 13, 2020
videoDescription: Today on CNN 10: The doctor is in! CNN's Dr. Sanjay Gupta joins us to discuss antibodies and their role in our immune system. After that, we're going underground (and back in time) for a rare, historic look at a world-famous subway system. And we show you how robot "dogs" are on patrol in Singapore to ensure proper social distancing.

videoTitle: New Theory About Famous Dinosaurs | May 12, 2020
videoDescription: From South Korea to Spain, and from Germany to China: We're going globetrotting today to report what's reopening (and what isn't) in different parts of the world. New theories about famous dinosaurs are contrasted with how the animals were presented in a 1993 movie. And an art student earns an A by building a miniature world around squirrels.

videoTitle: A Portal To Another World Explained
videoDescription: These gold-colored shipping containers open windows from one side of the world to another.s

videoTitle: Time For Creative Expression | May 11, 2020
videoDescription: Creative expression in the time of coronavirus is our first subject on today's program. And if you have the foggiest idea where the world's foggiest place might be, you'll have no trouble with 10-Second Trivia. After a report on fog, we're taking you lobster fishing in Maine. And we're making a splash in a "bearbath."

videoTitle: Can Robot Birds Protect Airports?
videoDescription: Clear Flight Solutions:  Is this the most effective bird control solution in the world?

videoTitle: How Your Mood Can Change The Color Of Your Clothes
videoDescription:
She calls herself a "material alchemist" and when she describes her work, she invokes both science and magic.  Lauren Bowker is the founder of The Unseen, a London design house whose creations have been exhibited in art, design and science museums around the world, from the Victoria and Albert Museum in London to The Museum of Science and Industry in Chicago.
It specializes in creating materials printed with inks that change color with fluctuations in light, temperature, moisture, pressure -- and even the user's emotions.

videoTitle: Can Technology Save Famous Art?
videoDescription: We meet the people pioneering the world's most high-tech painting conservation techniques at the Courtauld institute of Art.

videoTitle: How To Get Perfect Sound
videoDescription: Rob Harris explains the secrets of designing the acoustics for some of the world's most famous concert halls.

videoTitle: From The Beaches Of Florida To The Ancient World | April 22, 2020
videoDescription: What used to be known as "black gold" and "Texas tea" recently saw negative prices on the U.S. stock market for the first time in recorded history. After an explanation of that, we're taking you to the beaches of Florida for a report on a silver lining to the coronavirus pandemic. Then, get your passport ready for a trip to a city near the only remaining Wonder of the Ancient World.

videoTitle: Voting During A Pandemic And Flying Back 100 Years | April 16, 2020
videoDescription: With worldwide Covid-19 cases exceeding 2 million, South Korea gives us an idea of how upcoming elections could coincide with social distancing. And if you're a fan of aviation history, grab your scarf and goggles and prepare to take flight with the fighter planes of World War I.

videoTitle: Politics, Vaccines, And An Escape | April 10, 2020
videoDescription: U.S. political news tops off today's show. With contests postponed and campaigning done virtually, it's shaping up to be a different political season than America has ever seen before. Meanwhile, scientists worldwide race to develop a coronavirus vaccine. And we venture across the Atlantic to visit a historic and incredibly picturesque islet.

videoTitle: The Speed Of Recovery | April 3, 2020
videoDescription: Today, we're explaining how the speed at which the U.S. economy recovers from coronavirus depends on how things "shape up." That's followed by some geographic trivia and a trip to the world's second-largest desert. And we're showing you how sled dogs are helping make important deliveries for elderly people in Maine.

videoTitle: Where Do Cell Phones Go To Die?
videoDescription: Much of the world's electronic waste ends up in Guiyu, China, where old parts are recycled but chemicals like mercury leak into the water.

videoTitle: The 2 Trillion Dollar Debate | March 26, 2020
videoDescription: As lawmakers in the U.S. Congress debate a $2 trillion stimulus bill, today's show gives you a sense of what's in it. After that, we're looking at how consumers worldwide have impacted the global supply of toilet paper. And in the second installment of our virtual vacation series, we're taking a tour of Juneau, Alaska.

videoTitle: Virtual Vacation: Touring A Hawaiian Lava Tube | March 25, 2020
videoDescription: After reporting on more coronavirus-related lockdowns taking place worldwide, we're giving you a bit of an escape today. Our new series on "virtual vacations" launches with a tour of a Hawaiian lava tube. After that, we're showing you how a lockdown couldn't keep one Frenchman from running a marathon on his balcony.

videoTitle: Heroes Are Making A Difference | March 23, 2020
videoDescription: With coronavirus cases on the rise worldwide, the virus' potential to impact the Olympics increases with each passing day. How could this be particularly painful for Japan? We're also looking at the potential effects of a global recession and a possible U.S. government stimulus package. And the scores of people making a positive difference around the world are all Heroes in our book!

videoTitle: Fighting Misinformation | March 20, 2020
videoDescription: As information about coronavirus spreads faster than the disease itself, how can misinformation about it be addressed? As efforts to contain this disease reach historic proportions, comparisons are drawn between modern-day America and World War II America. And when a group of wayward ducks finds its way to a dangerous part of town, a police escort comes to help.

videoTitle: What Is A Pandemic?
videoDescription: The Spanish Flu in 1918 is considered one of the world's worst pandemics.  CNN takes a look at what pandemics are and how they can be stopped.

videoTitle: Why Do Volcanoes Erupt?
videoDescription:
More than 80% of the Earth's surface, both above and below sea level, is of volcanic origin.  Lava is molten rock from a volcano that reaches the Earth's surface. Liquid rock below the Earth's surface is referred to as magma.
More than 50% of the world's active volcanoes above sea level encircle the Pacific Ocean, forming the "Ring of Fire." The ring stretches from New Zealand to the coast of South America.

videoTitle: The Business Of The Oscars | February 10, 2020
videoDescription: Five months after a major hurricane directly hit the Bahamas, we're assessing the rebuilding efforts and explaining why recovery could take a long time. A day after the 92nd Academy Awards, we're examining the business aspect of the nomination process. And we're drawing you into the debate over how to pronounce the name of a world-famous artist.

videoTitle: Low Tides Reveal World War I-Era Submarine | January 15, 2019
videoDescription: A milestone has been passed in the partial shutdown of the U.S. government. An internationally significant vote takes place in the British Parliament. Low tides in France reveal the remains of a World War I-era submarine. And a strike begins in America's second-largest school district.

videoTitle: The World's Largest Annual Human Migration | January 23, 2020
videoDescription: A widely spreading virus coincides with the world's largest, annual human migration in China. Conservationists see success in a program to increase the numbers of a rare bird in New Zealand. And people in South Florida are warned to be on guard against falling iguanas, as temperatures reach unusual lows.

videoTitle: Plant-Based Alternatives To Sushi | January 17, 2019
videoDescription: We begin today's show with a report on terrorist attacks in Syria and Kenya. Then, we're taking you to Europe, where preparations are being made for the 49th meeting of the World Economic Forum. We sample some plant-based alternatives to sushi and nutrition bars. And we explain the natural phenomenon of a giant spinning disk made of ice.

videoTitle: Free Climbing Record: El Capitan | February 28, 2019
videoDescription: From a disputed territory in southern Asia to the summit of a U.S. landmark, we're climbing all over the world to bring you news today. You'll learn how Kashmir has been the subject of wars and skirmishes between India and Pakistan, and you'll find out how many bowls of soba noodles have to be eaten to set a record at a restaurant in Japan.

videoTitle: Towering Trash Heap Fires | March 4, 2019
videoDescription: We start off the week with two reports concerning Venezuela: One explains a spike in political tension, and the other follows people crossing a border to get the supplies they need. Our second stop is in eastern Asia, where fires at a towering trash heap are deeply concerning to residents nearby. And we're taking a ride on what will be the world's tallest dive coaster.

videoTitle: What It Looks Like When Jets Break The Sound Barrier | March 8, 2019
videoDescription: Today's show explains the significance of possible activity at a North Korean missile facility. We're also showing you what it "looks like" when jets break the sound barrier, and we're introducing a CNN Hero who uses video games to connect with children in hospitals. The world's largest snow maze rounds out a week of coverage on CNN 10.

videoTitle: Uber Drivers Protest Around the World | May 9, 2019
videoDescription: Iran partially withdraws from a 2015 nuclear agreement, and the U.S. imposes more sanctions on the Middle Eastern country. On the eve of Uber's entry into the U.S. stock market, some of its drivers from around the world hold a protest. And with Artificial Intelligence finding its way into the corporate world, we're examining some of its pros and cons in business.

videoTitle: Analysis of Boeing's Struggles | April 24, 2019
videoDescription: We're featuring a variety of stories from around the world this Wednesday, from an analysis of Boeing's struggles to a preview of an upcoming state visit between the leaders of the U.S. and the U.K. The advent of "wish-cycling" poses problems for waste management facilities, and a sanctuary helps sloths in Costa Rica.

videoTitle: Why Komodo Island Could Be Shut Down | April 4, 2019
videoDescription: We're traveling all over the world today, starting at the U.S. Capitol, where the leader of NATO addressed Congress. From there, we're reporting on India's elections and a downside of the nation's recent space achievement. We make a stop in Indonesia to explain why Komodo Island could be shut down next year. And we land in the sky above Arizona for a mesmerizing light show.

videoTitle: Devastating Fire At Notre Dame Cathedral | April 16, 2019
videoDescription: A devastating fire at the world's most famous Gothic cathedral is our first story this Tuesday. It's followed by a look at what many protesters want following a military coup in Sudan. We're also featuring a Positive Athlete report about a football quarterback who is working to overcome the loss of his sister.

videoTitle: Exploring the Largest Known Cave In The World | May 3, 2019
videoDescription: This Friday, CNN 10 is taking you from South Asia to South America. You'll hear about a cyclone that is bearing down on India, and you'll explore the largest known cave in the world. You'll also find out how an American spaceflight company plans to give tourists a few minutes of weightlessness.

videoTitle: Challenges Facing Modern Grocery Chains | May 20, 2019
videoDescription: Two rival countries on opposite sides of the world have been ramping up rhetoric against each other, but both are saying there will be no war. Today's show gets you up to speed on the tensions between the U.S. and Iran. Also featured: the dynamic challenges facing American grocery chains, the advent of a robotic window cleaner, and the work of two CNN Heroes to improve a girl's life.

videoTitle: Brexit Challenges Ahead | May 23, 2019
videoDescription: Almost two years and two months after the United Kingdom started the process of formally separating from the European Union, the Brexit continues to see challenges. In CNN's Freedom Project series, a Fijian woman describes a life of forced labor in another free country. And in the capital of South Korea, a group of pyrotechnics experts uniquely illuminates the Lotte World Tower.

videoTitle: India Election Results | May 24, 2019
videoDescription: Early election results from India headline today's edition of CNN 10. Afterward, we're sitting down with a world explorer to discuss what he's learned about societies where people live longer.

videoTitle: Dangerous Climbing Season For Mt. Everest | May 28, 2019
videoDescription: As CNN 10 begins its last week of coverage for the 2019 Winter-Spring season, we're explaining the resignation of Britain's prime minister. That's followed by a recap of Memorial Day events in the U.S. Then, we're taking you to the world's highest peak, which has seen a dangerous and deadly climbing season.

videoTitle: Problems Involving Lead and Tap Water in Newark, New Jersey | August 19, 2019
videoDescription: Problems involving lead and tap water have grown in Newark, New Jersey, and they're drawing some comparisons to ongoing troubles in Flint, Michigan. A panel of mountain climbers and government officials has released guidelines for limiting future crowds on Mount Everest. And a 103-year-old woman reportedly sets a new record for world's oldest tandem skydiver.

videoTitle: Using Boxing to Help Young People in Chicago | August 22, 2019
videoDescription: A meeting between two world leaders has been postponed, and the reason why centers on the world's largest island. A CNN Hero uses the sport of boxing to help young people in Chicago succeed. And a time capsule is opened in the state of New Hampshire, but the event brings more questions than answers.

videoTitle: World Leaders Meet in France | August 26, 2019
videoDescription: As the leaders of the world's seven largest economies meet in France, we're reporting on some of the issues they're discussing, including the wildfires that are scorching parts of the Amazon. A bit of Olympic trivia follows, coupled with a report on a "city of waterways."

videoTitle: Resurgence of Tin Mining | September 6, 2019
videoDescription: We're taking you all around the world this Friday on CNN 10. First, we have a look at how Hurricane Dorian is impacting the southeastern U.S. Then, we're examining how India hopes a moon landing today makes for manned missions tomorrow. We make a stop in southwestern England to explain a potential resurgence of tin mining. And we wrap up in Japan, where a humanoid robot just became a towering record holder.

videoTitle: Large Protests Spreading Around the Globe | October 24, 2019
videoDescription: Turkey has agreed to stop its military operation in northern Syria, and the U.S. has lifted its sanctions on Turkey. But the Middle East isn't the only unstable part of the world, and military action isn't the only expression of instability. Today's show illustrates how large protests over a variety of issues are spreading around the globe.

videoTitle: An Indian Mission to the Moon | September 10, 2019
videoDescription: Events around the world (and beyond) take us far and wide today on CNN 10. An Indian mission to the moon, a pair of typhoons in Asia, and the "battle for the Balkans" are three of our subjects. And a CNN reporter in the Bahamas shows you how a community was cut off by Hurricane Dorian.

videoTitle: Strike at General Motors | September 17, 2019
videoDescription: The topics we're explaining today include a general election in Israel, a strike involving General Motors, and the pros and cons of taking a company public. A report on the world's busiest airport and a simulation of what it's like to land there round out our coverage.

videoTitle: Recent Rise and Fall of Oil Prices | September 18, 2019
videoDescription: CNN 10 is explaining a recent rise and fall in oil prices and how they're tied to an attack on Saudi Arabian oil facilities. Afterward, a pair of scientific stories highlight studies on sharks and rats. And we're jumping into a 10 out of 10 segment featuring the world's largest bounce house.

videoTitle: A 2022 World Cup Tour | November 22, 2019
videoDescription: Uncertainty weighs on Israel's government following political deadlock and the announcement of formal charges against its prime minister. After reporting on that, we're taking a tour of one of the venues of the 2022 World Cup.

videoTitle: Historic Travel Company Goes Out of Business | September 24, 2019
videoDescription: A historic British travel company has gone out of business, impacting hundreds of thousands of people worldwide. A debate over coal plays a role at the United Nations General Assembly. And we show you what life is like for a fire lookout on a lonely mountaintop in the Montana wilderness.

videoTitle: The World's Longest Commercial Flight | October 22, 2019
videoDescription: Officials and residents in Dallas, Texas are assessing the damage from a recent tornado. Medical researchers are working with an Australian airline to assess the physiological effects of the world's longest commercial flight. And inventors are assessing the effectiveness of new technology in helping people with disabilities.

videoTitle: The World's Two Most-Populated Nations | October 1, 2019
videoDescription: The world's two most-populated nations are featured on our show this Tuesday. We start in China, where a massive military parade is part of a 70th anniversary commemoration. And we make a stop in India, where one man started a movement to clean up a trashed beach. Also featured: an explanation of how primaries and caucuses play out in advance of a U.S. presidential election.

videoTitle: Back-and-Forth: U.S. and Iran | January 6, 2020
videoDescription: CNN 10 is kicking off a new year of explaining news from around the world! Our first reports of 2020 center on events in the Middle East, Oceania and Asia

videoTitle: How Effective is the Flu Shot? | December 12, 2019
videoDescription: New restrictions on Americans' visits to Cuba are the topic of today's first report. It's followed by a look at an early flu season in the U.S. A project to clean up the world's oceans sees some progress after setbacks, and a "tunnel of lights" turns a Tennessee bridge into a winter wonderland.

videoTitle: Why Russia is Banned from the Olympics | December 10, 2019
videoDescription:
December 10, 2019 -
Russian sports are dealt another blow from the World Anti-Doping Agency, though they plan to appeal a four-year partial ban on international competition. Strains form in the rollercoaster relationship between the United States and North Korea. A volcano in New Zealand erupts while tourists are on it. And a new device could help police wrap up fleeing suspects.

videoTitle: Objectivity In Journalism
videoDescription:
It's time to go behind the scenes.  How do we stay objective on CNN 10? 

We're explaining that as part of a partnership with AT&T's Youth Voices Collective, in a series of special editions featuring yours truly... and student questions about journalism.

videoTitle: Checking Your Sources
videoDescription:
It's time to go behind the scenes.  How do you know what news sources to trust?

We're explaining that as part of a partnership with AT&T's Youth Voices Collective, in a series of special editions featuring yours truly... and student questions about journalism.

videoTitle: On Camera Delivery
videoDescription:
It's time to go behind the scenes.  We're here to provide a few tips for being yourself, when you're on camera.

We're explaining that as part of a partnership with AT&T's Youth Voices Collective, in a series of special editions featuring yours truly... and student questions about journalism.

videoTitle: Effective Newswriting
videoDescription:
It's time to go behind the scenes.  How do you know become an effective news writer?

We're explaining that as part of a partnership with AT&T's Youth Voices Collective, in a series of special editions featuring yours truly... and student questions about journalism.

videoTitle: Life And Legacy Of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.
videoDescription:
CNN 10 is collaborating with the AT&T Youth Voices Collective to help amplify youth voices. In celebration of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., we’d like to welcome the students of the Harvard Diversity Project to share portions of some of Dr. King’s most famous and influential speeches. The Harvard Diversity Project, based in Dr. King’s own hometown of Atlanta, is a pipeline program that recruits, trains, and matriculates highly motivated Black youth into a summer debate residency at Harvard.
(AT&T YVC Partners: 826 National, Six Feet of Separation & Vox ATL)

videoTitle: Cleaning Up Space Junk | December 13, 2019
videoDescription: CNN 10 is featuring reports on an election in the United Kingdom and some global efforts to clean up space. An "emotionally intelligent" robot upgrade is headed to the International Space Station. And our show concludes with a rhyming tribute to the thousands of viewers who visited us this year.

videoTitle: A Look Back at Japan's Attack on Pearl Harbor | December 9, 2019
videoDescription: "A date that will live in infamy" is remembered on CNN 10, more than 78 years after the Pearl Harbor attack was carried out. Our other reports include a prisoner exchange between two rival nations and a company's use of artificial intelligence to detect and track wildfires.

videoTitle: Early Facebook Feature That Caused a Heated Controversy | December 6, 2019
videoDescription: A special report on Facebook, a company whose monthly user base includes one quarter of the global population. We're looking at an early feature of the application that redefined it while causing a heated controversy.

videoTitle: Exploring the Founding of Facebook | December 5, 2019
videoDescription: The massive social media company Facebook celebrates its 15th birthday, CNN 10 kicks off a special report today examining the huge successes, huge failures, and unique challenges the business has faced. We start by exploring the "mission" of the man who founded the company.

videoTitle: What is NATO? | December 4, 2019
videoDescription: NATO's 29 members meet in London, CNN 10 is exploring the history of the organization and some of the discussions about its future. We're explaining why some scientists think underwater speakers could help revitalize dead coral reefs. And we're taking a tour of a 1960s-era home that was considered futuristic before it became historic.

videoTitle: A record for Black Friday | December 2, 2019
videoDescription: Iraq's prime minister resigns after months of protests. Online sales set a record on Black Friday. Musicians help rehabilitate inmates by teaching them to compose and play classical music. And a new kind of "skin" helps robots react to changes around them. All of these stories and more are featured on CNN 10 today!

videoTitle: Why Uber is Losing a License | November 26, 2019
videoDescription: CNN 10 is explaining why Uber has lost its license to operate in London -- and what kind of impact that could have. From there, we're traveling to Japan to discuss innovation and "unicorns." And we're showing you how the U.S. Naval Academy's Sea Trials put freshmen to the ultimate physical test.

videoTitle: Tour a Glacier in Alaska | November 21, 2019
videoDescription: Fire and ice are the first two topics on today's show. We're updating you on the ongoing fight against bushfires in parts of Australia, and we're taking you on a tour of a famous glacier in Alaska. A new study may shed some light on why babies hiccup, and a giant panda ventures across the Pacific to his new home.

videoTitle: U.S. Policy Shift on Israel | November 20, 2019
videoDescription: A U.S. policy shift concerning the nation of Israel is the first event we're explaining today on CNN 10. After that, we're looking at the advent of plant-based meat alternatives and exploring some of their upsides and downsides. And we're watching a real-life "Iron Man" suit up and break his own record.

videoTitle: Insect Decline in the United Kingdom | November 19, 2019
videoDescription: We're starting in Iran and examining some of the reasons behind nationwide protests in the theocratic republic. As part of a report on an insect decline in the United Kingdom, we're sharing some of a biologist's recommendations for how people can help the six-legged creatures. And we're explaining the role of robots in disaster response.

videoTitle: Health Concerns for Astronauts | November 18, 2019
videoDescription: Blood flow and blood clots: Are these additional health concerns for astronauts eyeing deep-space missions? That story is followed by a look at how some students are leaving Hong Kong for mainland China amid ongoing violence in the Special Administrative Region. And we're taking you to Venice, where recent high tides have made their mark on historic structures.

videoTitle: Record-Breaking Cold in the U.S. | November 14, 2019
videoDescription: From record-breaking cold in the U.S. to near-record floods in part of Italy, today's edition of CNN 10 starts with the weather. That's followed by a down-the-middle report on the political divide in America. And a 33-year-old multisport athlete lives out his philosophy of "no excuses."

videoTitle: Why the Rainforest is Shrinking | November 12, 2019
videoDescription: Bolivia and Borneo are two of our stops today on CNN 10. We're explaining why the South American country is in a state of political upheaval, and we're exploring several reasons why the Pacific island's rainforest is shrinking. Finally, a coalition of "cheetahs" draws researchers and onlookers at MIT.

videoTitle: The Fall of the Berlin Wall | November 11, 2019
videoDescription: Deadly bushfires have flared up in Australia, and even though the state of New South Wales is prone to these disasters, firefighters say the worst may still be ahead. After that report, we're featuring a look back on the 30th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall. We're also looking at the origins of Veterans Day and explaining now a program teams up former servicemen and women with former professional athletes.

videoTitle: Explaining Targeted Political Ads | November 8, 2019
videoDescription: Explaining why targeted political advertisements are controversial on social media -- and how some companies are addressing the issue. From there, we're traveling to Poland's capital, where a museum dedicated to neon is taking visitors back in time. And we're revealing the names and the work of the top 10 CNN Heroes of 2019.

videoTitle: The Driverless Future | November 7, 2019
videoDescription: Though fully automated driving may be decades away, we're exploring what city roadways could look like if everything goes as hoped by the manufacturers and supporters of driverless technology. And we're considering how driverless cars could change the look of American cities themselves.

videoTitle: Why Mosquitoes Are Attracted to You | November 6, 2019
videoDescription: The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers changes its risk characterization for a dam in California. Recent research suggests that body odor helps determine how attractive people are to mosquitoes. And when he's not acting or modeling, a French swimmer sets his sights on the upcoming Tokyo Paralympic Games.

videoTitle: Record Smog in India | November 5, 2019
videoDescription: Officials in India's capital are aware of what's causing near-record levels of smog, but they're struggling to find solutions. The remains of the "Iron Scow" are shaken loose near Niagara Falls for the first time in more than a century. And a company hopes its app will revolutionize transportation in South Africa, but it has a big drawback for some commuters.

videoTitle: The End of Daylight-Saving Time | November 4, 2019
videoDescription: A down-the-middle explanation of the recent impeachment inquiry vote in the U.S. House of Representatives. It's followed by a report looking at several indicators surrounding the U.S. economy. And daylight-saving time has officially ended in the U.S., but it's become more of a standard than standard time.

videoTitle: Is Amazon a Monopoly? | November 1, 2019
videoDescription: A special edition of CNN 10 focuses on Amazon, the $1 trillion U.S. company that has changed the retail landscape. We'll explore some of the technology it uses, the challenges it has faced and created, the concerns about whether it's a monopoly, and the profits it has generate

videoTitle: The Business of Halloween | October 31, 2019
videoDescription: An update from California leads off today's show, as at least 10 wildfires burn across the state. From there, we're reporting on a significant rule change from the NCAA. And amid substantial (but not record) American spending on Halloween, we're examining the business side of selling candy.

videoTitle: The Flawed Boeing 737 MAX | October 30, 2019
videoDescription: The CEO of Boeing testifies on Capitol Hill, one year after a fatal plane crash took place that was later linked to flawed computer software in Boeing jets. Great white shark sightings disappear in a place that's famous for them, creating a mystery for scientists. And a dryer maintenance company makes history with a giant ball of lint.

videoTitle: Hong Kong Protests Lead to Recession? | October 29, 2019
videoDescription: We start in California today to report on three of the wildfires that are scorching different parts of the state. From there, we're headed to Asia to explain a potential recession in Hong Kong and the opening of a new airport in Beijing, China. And we're telling you what a couple in Michigan thought when they found a satellite that had landed in their yard.

videoTitle: The Difference Between Debt and Deficit | October 28, 2019
videoDescription: A U.S. raid on a terrorist leader and a report differentiating debt from deficit are our first two topics this Monday. They're followed by a visit to an extraordinary art exhibit in France. And we're explaining how a single seed grew into a pumpkin that literally floats a farmer's boat.

videoTitle: The New Emperor of Japan | October 25, 2019
videoDescription: A mysterious oil spill is washing up crude on beaches across northeastern Brazil. A new emperor has formally announced his ascension to the throne in Japan. A Medieval sword in stone has been excavated in Bosnia and Herzegovina. And a CNN Hero makes more progress in helping victims of spinal cord injuries.

videoTitle: Female Astronauts Make History | October 21, 2019
videoDescription: What could be the reasons for obstructions that were recently observed at high-rises in North Korea's capital? What happened over the weekend concerning the Brexit process? How did two NASA astronauts recently make history? And how could a "blob" be a tourist attraction? These are today's topics on CNN 10.

videoTitle: Will Parliament Approve Brexit Deal? | October 18, 2019
videoDescription: A Brexit deal has been reached between Britain's government and the European Union, but will it be approved by Parliament? Turkey has agreed to pause its incursion into northern Syria, but is lasting peace on the horizon? These are two of today's topics on CNN 10. And we're introducing you to a man whose job is to make sure he pronounces every word correctly.

videoTitle: Pros and Cons of E-Scooters | October 17, 2019
videoDescription: As a potential "bomb cyclone" threatens the U.S. Northeast, we're explaining these weather events and exploring the characteristics of Nor'easters. As electric scooters cover sidewalks in U.S. cities, we're examining their pros and cons from transportation and investment standpoints. And as the Empire State Building reopens during a $160 million renovation, we're checking out the new view.

videoTitle: Concussions: Good News, Bad News | October 16, 2019
videoDescription: Following the deadliest storm to strike Japan in years, we're updating you on the recovery efforts and exploring the technology that helps track typhoons. A new study on concussions yields some good news and bad news when it comes to high school sports. And three billionaires set their sights on space.

videoTitle: Queen's Speech Tradition | October 14, 2019
videoDescription: In Japan, the recovery process begins following Typhoon Hagibis. In the United Kingdom, pageantry and tradition accompany the Queen's speech. In Germany, an American gymnast sets a new record. And in California's Channel Islands, a relatively small mammal makes a comeback.

videoTitle: Kites as Conduits for Wind Power | October 11, 2019
videoDescription: Our first two stories today concern a super typhoon that's spinning toward Japan and a U.S. automotive industry strike that's entering its 25th day. After that, we're examining highly advanced kites as possible conduits for wind energy. And we're introducing a CNN Hero whose mission is to help senior citizens complete their bucket lists.

videoTitle: History of the Nobel Prize | October 10, 2019
videoDescription: Turkey has begun a military operation in northern Syria, and today's show explains why and what some other countries are saying about it. We're also covering the history and prestige of the Nobel Prize, and we're examining why a California utility company decided to cut electricity for hundreds of thousands of people. Finally, a reusable container company hopes to close the "loop" on plastic waste.

videoTitle: The NBA's Challenge With China | October 9, 2019
videoDescription: What began with a tweet has become a major challenge for the NBA in the nation where it has the most fans. What began as an investigation of Saturn's moons has yielded a new superlative for the ringed planet. And what began as an effort to conserve a rare butterfly has resulted in more blue wings flitting around Southern California.

videoTitle: Global Shipping Rule Changes | October 8, 2019
videoDescription: A U.S. troop withdrawal from the border between Syria and Turkey has ripple effects in the region. The global shipping industry is preparing for a rule change concerning fuel. And artists with disabilities find a space to thrive at a studio in California.

videoTitle: Technology Attempts to Unravel Ancient Roman Scrolls | October 7, 2019
videoDescription: Diplomats from the United States and North Korea just wrapped up talks in Sweden, but accounts differ on their progress. The U.S. has seen a dramatic increase in the number of Eastern equine encephalitis cases, and we're exploring some of the possible reasons why. And scientists use new technology in an attempt to "unravel" some ancient Roman scrolls.

videoTitle: The Island Full of Komodo Dragons | October 4, 2019
videoDescription: Protests in Iraq lead off today's edition of CNN 10, and we're explaining the grievances of the demonstrators and the response by the government. Then, we're taking you to Indonesia, where officials have reversed plans to close a popular tourist island. And a CNN Hero works to bring healing to the South Side of Chicago.

videoTitle: Should College Athletes Be Paid? | October 3, 2019
videoDescription: Should college athletes get paid? The debate has flared up again following the passage of a California law that goes against NCAA rules, and we explore multiple arguments today on CNN 10. We also report on the bankruptcy filing of a popular American retailer. And we examine both the calculation and the creativity involved in branding.

videoTitle: The Challenges of Colonizing Mars | October 2, 2019
videoDescription: Violence flares up in Hong Kong as China commemorates 70 years of Communist rule. An octopus is observed changing color in its sleep, which may indicate that the animal is capable of dreaming. And though the technology doesn't yet exist for humans to visit Mars, a number of researchers are addressing the challenges of colonizing the red planet.

videoTitle: Private Spaceflight Makes Progress | September 30, 2019
videoDescription: An early winter storm has slammed into the northern Rocky Mountains, and we're explaining how it could set new records. A spaceflight company announces progress in its work, but an official at NASA wants the pace picked up. And a CNN Hero once again takes his cooking skills and his kindness to people in need.

videoTitle: Different Views on the Impeachment Inquiry | September 26, 2019
videoDescription: A down-the-middle explanation of events surrounding an impeachment inquiry is our first topic today. You'll hear several voices and perspectives about the political news coming out of Washington, D.C. Also featured: a sea otter rehabilitation program and a park filled with "trolls."

videoTitle: Life in the Wake of Hurricane Dorian | September 23, 2019
videoDescription: Tensions concerning the Middle Eastern country of Iran compose our first story of the week. That's followed by an update on life in the Bahamas in the wake of Hurricane Dorian. And after a report on renovations at a U.S. landmark, we're explaining why an Asian country is offering young people an escape from smartphone use.

videoTitle: The Significance of Lowered Interest Rates | September 20, 2019
videoDescription: What's left of Tropical Storm Imelda soaks parts of Texas. The U.S. Federal Reserve lowers interest rates, and we're explaining the history and significance of such decisions. And we're saddling up to go mountain biking, but we're going with an athlete who prefers the challenge of riding only one wheel.

videoTitle: Polls Close in Israel's General Election | September 19, 2019
videoDescription: With polls closed following its most recent general election, the nation of Israel waits to see how its next government shapes up. With slowing smartphone sales and other challenges facing Samsung, the company hopes innovation will help it keep its edge. And with a trip to New Zealand comes a look at a cave-dwelling creature that glows in the dark.

videoTitle: The Complicated Relationship between the U.S. and Saudi Arabia | September 16, 2019
videoDescription: After bringing you up to speed on a weekend attack on Saudi Arabian oil facilities, we're taking a look at the complicated relationship between the U.S. and Saudi Arabia. Afterward, our international coverage takes us to Hong Kong, where there's no end in sight for months of large protests.

videoTitle: Fukishima's Contaminated Water | September 12, 2019
videoDescription: More than eight years after a tsunami led to a meltdown at a Japanese nuclear plant, the issue of contaminated water poses a growing challenge for the Asian country. In the U.S., more illnesses have been linked to vaping, and the government is moving to ban flavored e-cigarette products. And with the U.S. political season heating up, we're looking at some do's and dont's when it comes to debating.

videoTitle: What It Was Like to Anchor on 9/11 | September 11, 2019
videoDescription: The focus of our show this September 11, 2019: the terrorist attacks that changed America 18 years ago. We're presenting a timeline of the events of September 11, 2001, and we're speaking to a former CNN anchor to get a sense of what it was like to cover such tragic and momentous news.

videoTitle: DNA Study of Loch Ness | September 9, 2019
videoDescription: Our first story of the week explains recent events involving the United States, Afghanistan, and the Taliban. We also give you a sense of what it's like to report inside a Taliban-controlled area. From there, we're looking at some of Hurricane Dorian's effects on Canada, the American Eastern Seaboard, and the northern Bahamas. And we're examining the results of a DNA study of a famous Scottish lake.

videoTitle: Space Missions Targeting Asteroids | September 5, 2019
videoDescription: A controversial proposal is scrapped in Hong Kong. An airport is utterly destroyed in the Bahamas. A tech company pays a record fine for allegedly violating a law that protects children's privacy. A pair of space missions target asteroids. And an uninvited bear takes a nap in a Montana restroom.

videoTitle: Status of the Brexit Process | September 4, 2019
videoDescription: After an update on Hurricane Dorian and an early look at the destruction it caused in the Bahamas, we're examining the status of the Brexit process in Europe. That's followed by a report on why a husband was arrested in Singapore for accompanying his wife to her airport gate.

videoTitle: Hurricane Dorian's Projected Path | September 3, 2019
videoDescription: An update on Hurricane Dorian, including its destructive path across the Bahamas and its uncertain route near Florida, is today's first subject on CNN 10. We're also introducing you to a CNN Hero who's made it his life's work to rescue donkeys, and we're showing you what a field of dreams looks like for the ultimate college football fan.

videoTitle: Wildfires Burning in the Amazon | August 30, 2019
videoDescription: As Hurricane Dorian spins toward the U.S., we're taking a look at where it's expected to go, how powerful it's expected to be, and how Americans in its path are preparing. From there, we're updating you on the status of wildfires burning in the Amazon rainforest. And we're showing you how a young running back used footwork and handiwork to score a touchdown.

videoTitle: How Hurricanes Are Named | August 29, 2019
videoDescription: Today's show takes you from Atlantic to Pacific. First, we're explaining why forecasters expect Hurricane Dorian to strengthen and how storms like it get their names. We then have a feature on a "Starhopper" that could one day be used to help people land on other planets. And we're wrapping up the show with looks at adventure tourism and a sea of pumice.

videoTitle: Opioids Lead To A Public Health Emergency | August 28, 2019
videoDescription: Our first story today explains a closely watched legal decision involving a major pharmaceutical company and opioids.
