videoTitle: What Is A Recession? | September 27, 2022
videoDescription: This Tuesday, we're looking at why Americans fear a recession could be on the way while others feel it may already be here.  And Florida declares a state of emergency as it braces for a major hurricane expected to make landfall later this week.  We also travel to the Asian continent where many countries are dropping their Covid-19 restrictions as the region looks to rebound from the shutdowns.

videoTitle: Headlines From Around The World | September 26, 2022
videoDescription: Today, we travel to the country of Iran where nationwide protests continue following the death of a woman in government custody.  We also take a scientific look inside Hurricane Fiona as it approached the coast of Canada. And finally, we get an update from NASA as its spacecraft nears the end of its mission to crash into an asteroid.

videoTitle: A Military Mobilization In Russia | September 23, 2022
videoDescription: This Friday, we're explaining anti-war protests in Russia and monitoring an announcement that could send more Russian citizens to the battlefield.  We'll also go on a trip to Minnesota to meet up with a legendary hiker and explore some iconic spots around Lake Superior and Tettegouche State Park.

videoTitle: The First Day Of Fall | September 22, 2022
videoDescription: It's officially fall and today we're explaining the science behind the autumnal equinox.  We're also traveling to Australia to learn about a scientist using a network of sound recording devices to track an endangered species of bird. And finally, our own Coy Wire chats with two sports icons about their secrets to success.

videoTitle: Following Hurricane Fiona | September 21, 2022
videoDescription: This Wednesday, we're heading to the Caribbean island of Puerto Rico to understand its challenges following Hurricane Fiona.  Flooding and power outages remain widespread.  We'll also meet a New Jersey teacher who is distributing hundreds of thousands of free books to his local community.  And bonus: our all-week U.S. constitution trivia continues...

videoTitle: Explaining The Balance Of Power In The U.S. Congress | September 20, 2022
videoDescription: With less than 50 days until the U.S. Midterm elections, we're explaining the balance of power in the U.S. Congress.  We're also heading to space to understand an earth-protecting mission hoping to crash into an asteroid.

videoTitle: Headlines From Around The World | September 19, 2022
videoDescription: We're traveling the world today to examine some international headlines from Puerto Rico to Taiwan and the United Kingdom. Then, we're visiting with a CNN Hero who is turning food waste into meals for millions.

videoTitle: Trains Agree To Keep Moving? | September 16, 2022
videoDescription: On this Friday edition of CNN 10, we're exploring the latest efforts to avoid a strike among rail workers that could have sweeping effects on the supply chain, and we're going deep sea diving off the coast of Central America.

videoTitle: Does Twitter Have A Bot Problem? | September 15, 2022
videoDescription: This Thursday, we're breaking down rising prices in the U.S., and we're trying to understand just how many fake accounts exist on Twitter.

videoTitle: Flooding In Pakistan, A Newborn Star, And A CNN Hero | September 14, 2022
videoDescription: Today we're exploring parts of Pakistan that have been devastated by severe monsoon rains, we're taking a look at just released images of newborn stars, and we're meeting a CNN Hero who is turning discarded tech into life-changing opportunity.

videoTitle: An NFL Player's Journey | September 13, 2022
videoDescription: Today we check in on the war in Ukraine, look back at a "moonshot" of a speech, and interview an inspiring NFL player on this Tuesday edition of CNN 10.

videoTitle: The Next Mission To The Moon | September 12, 2022
videoDescription: CNN 10 is kicking off its first show of the 2022 fall season!  Today, we’re looking back at the life and legacy of Britain’s Queen Elizabeth II, we’re observing remembrances of the lives lost on September 11th, 2001, and we’re featuring an update on NASA’s next mission to the moon.

videoTitle: People Are Still Quitting
videoDescription: People are leaving their jobs in droves, and the issue isn't limited to the United States. Today's show begins by explaining some likely reasons why. Afterward, we're headed to the Central American nation of Belize to examine efforts to conserve a big cat. And we make a stop in Texas' Gulf Coast for a rare look at an escaped flamingo.

videoTitle: Heatwaves And Holograms
videoDescription: Heatwaves, holograms and hotels are all discussed today on CNN 10. We're covering near-record temperatures in India, and we're examining the potential application of holograms to medical procedures. Afterward, we're seeing what space looks like from some tourists' recent perspective, and we're checking out a potential space resort.

videoTitle: A Storm On The Sun
videoDescription: A major financial institution is warning that the U.S. economy could slip into recession in the months to come. Today's show explains the what, when and how related to the warning. Afterward, we're reporting on a recent solar storm. And we're examining some of the pros and cons of tidal energy, as more companies attempt to harness it.

videoTitle: Measuring The Snowpack
videoDescription: A change in U.S. immigration policy could further complicate conditions at America's border with Mexico. Reduced snowpack in the Sierra Nevada mountains is another symptom of an ongoing drought in California. And researchers have invented a new type of slime that could find roles in electronics and medicine.

videoTitle: Never Before Seen Views Of The Sun
videoDescription: Two space probes take the heat as they approach our nearest star and investigate solar weather. Inflation hits spring break budgets, prompting some Americans to alter their plans for the summer. And a cola company teams up with a pancake company to create a unique (and extra syrupy) soda.

videoTitle: Time For A Walk In Space
videoDescription: All 30 leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization are meeting this week in Belgium. What do they hope to accomplish? A day after dozens of reported tornadoes struck Texas, at least one takes a toll on part of New Orleans. Today's show also reports on a half-day walk in space and a breakdown of the factors in gas prices.

videoTitle: Why Are People Leaving Hong Kong?
videoDescription: Tens of thousands of people are leaving the city of Hong Kong, even though it's planning to relax some of its strict Covid measures in the weeks ahead. Severe weather has struck the American South, as a large storm system moves toward the Atlantic. And a massive engineering project finally wraps up in London, extending the city's famous Underground.

videoTitle: Cost To Fill An Airplane Gas Tank?
videoDescription: The rising costs of jet fuel are starting to impact airline ticket prices, and today's show explains several factors involved. For the first time since 2018, the U.S. Federal Reserve has raised interest rates. In the French capital, the Eiffel Tower grows taller by 20 feet. And at MIT, researchers develop a kind of "listening" fabric.

videoTitle: The Effort To Rebuild Notre Dame Cathedral
videoDescription: Is the United States about to do away with "standard time" and eliminate time changes altogether? That's our first topic this Thursday, and it's followed by a trip to France, where we're examining progress in the effort to rebuild Notre Dame Cathedral. And if you tried to break the M&M stacking record and failed, you'll find you're in good company.

videoTitle: What Is The Ring Of Fire? | December 6, 2021
videoDescription: A new week of coverage begins in Indonesia, where a deadly volcanic eruption has covered some Javanese villages in a thick coat of ash. New travel rules take effect for air travelers headed to the U.S. The last surviving U.S. Army officer of the "Band of Brothers" has passed away at age 99. And a French "speedcuber" solves a popular puzzle using only one hand.

videoTitle: A Lockout In Major League Baseball | December 3, 2021
videoDescription: First up this Friday, we're explaining a standoff between NATO and Russia over recent events near Ukraine. The 2022 Winter Olympics are less than three months away, but related uncertainty and controversy are making headlines. There's been a lockout in Major League Baseball for the first time in decades. And the "Home Alone" house goes up for rent.

videoTitle: Relocating Rhinos | December 2, 2021
videoDescription: As experts debate whether a new coronavirus variant will affect the U.S. economy, we're examining the impact of inflation on American farmers. That report is followed by a look at an effort to help a species of rhinoceros by relocating dozens of these mammals. And we're explaining how a wayward goat's "vanity" landed him back in the pen.

videoTitle: A Hurricane Season Ends | December 1, 2021
videoDescription: The mysterious "omicron" variant of Covid-19, the resignation of a social media CEO, and the conclusion of the Atlantic hurricane season are today's first subjects. We're explaining why experts are saying not to procrastinate on holiday shopping. And we're visiting a controversial Christmas tree at a Canadian mall.

videoTitle: A Caribbean Island Nation Becomes A Republic | November 30, 2021
videoDescription: Once a parliamentary democracy under a constitutional monarchy, the Caribbean island nation of Barbados officially becomes a republic. In California, a high school football team whose players are deaf wins out on its way to a championship game. And an ingenious toy fanatic builds a massive "Nerf" gun.

videoTitle: What Happens To Our Online Returns? | November 29, 2021
videoDescription: Scientists have identified a new variant of Covid-19, but it's too soon to tell if it will spread like previous versions. American consumers return to in-person shopping, but the numbers are still down from 2019. We feature an in-depth report on what happens to goods when we return them. And an 11-month-old learns to snowboard in China.

videoTitle: Test Driving A "Self Driving" Car On A Busy Street | November 23, 2021
videoDescription: On the heels of last week's report about pollution in India, today's show takes you to a dangerously smoggy city in Pakistan. After a bit of trivia, we're taking a test drive in New York City of a car in autonomous mode. And an annual crab migration is under way on an island in the Indian Ocean.

videoTitle: Toxic Air Causing Problems | November 18, 2021
videoDescription: Pollution thickens across parts of India, turning the air toxic and leading to a rise in breathing problems, but finding a solution remains a challenge. We're reporting on the plight of sunflower stars, whose numbers have dramatically decreased along the Pacific coast of North America. And we're explaining how a text to the wrong number led to a years-long friendship.

videoTitle: Mixing Masks Into Concrete | November 17, 2021
videoDescription: Today's show begins with news from the U.S. Pacific Northwest, where heavy rainfall has caused a range of problems in several states. From there, we're taking you to the border between Belarus and Poland for an update on a migrant crisis. An effort to recycle discarded facemasks and a controversial satellite strike round out our coverage.

videoTitle: A Virtual Reality Gym | November 16, 2021
videoDescription: From the U.S. state with the highest gas prices to the U.S. city with the highest inflation rate, today's show takes you cross-country for a look at some economic challenges facing many Americans. That report is followed by a visit to a gym that uses virtual reality headsets to digitally enhance its workouts.

videoTitle: Breaking Down Digital Money | November 15, 2021
videoDescription: As some governments look to launch their own forms of cryptocurrency (while at the same time regulating it), we kick off the week with a look at the pros and cons of the digital money. Meanwhile, some retailers and farmers are warning that Christmas trees may not be as plentiful this season. But this year's famous Rockefeller Tree has been cut and carried to the Big Apple.

videoTitle: Inflation, Veterans Day, And General Electric Splits | November 11, 2021
videoDescription: For the first time in 96 years, members of the public have been allowed to lay flowers at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier. We'll explain why this Veterans Day. And we'll update you on the status of inflation in the American economy and the decision of General Electric to split into three smaller businesses.

videoTitle: Reconnecting Fragmented Forests | November 10, 2021
videoDescription: A surge of migrants at Belarus' borders with European Union countries brings challenges for officials in the region. A conservationist works to reconnect fragmented forests in South America. And a castle hits the real estate market in Connecticut.

videoTitle: Creating A Bubble Barrier | November 9, 2021
videoDescription: A memorial has been placed and an investigation is under way following a tragedy at a concert in Houston, Texas. A simple, low-impact "bubble barrier" helps keep plastic out of the sea in the Netherlands. And a moose on the loose could make a great recruit for a South Dakota football team.

videoTitle: Jobs Of The Future | November 5, 2021
videoDescription: A crisis deepens in Ethiopia as atrocities are reported in the nation's civil war. An organization works to train American factory workers for the jobs of the future. And three Rhode Island trick-or-treaters perform an act of kindness when they come across an empty Halloween candy bowl.

videoTitle: Most Expensive Thanksgiving Ever | November 4, 2021
videoDescription: A quick check of headlines leads things off today, as we update you on a vaccine decision by the U.S. government and the outcomes of two gubernatorial races. From there, we're explaining why this Thanksgiving could be the most expensive ever in terms of grocery bills. And we're visiting the nation of India to observe a new machine that could lead to improved air quality.

videoTitle: Disruptions In Airline Travel | November 3, 2021
videoDescription: Disruptions in U.S. airline travel -- and what could that mean for the weeks ahead -- are the focus of today's first report on CNN 10. From there, we're having a look at how China has maintained tight restrictions concerning Covid while other countries have begun to relax theirs. A robot "cook" and a Northern Lights show round out today’s coverage.

videoTitle: A New Planet In A Far Away Galaxy? | October 29, 2021
videoDescription: In what might be a first for science, researchers say they may have discovered a new planet in a galaxy far, far away -- but it could be decades before they know for sure. Back on Earth, a famous volcano keeps up its streak of 2021 eruptions. And a company hopes its products made with seaweed will help replace the use of plastic.

videoTitle: Less Than 100 Days Until The Olympics | October 28, 2021
videoDescription: Less than 100 days until China hosts the 2022 Winter Olympics, questions are being asked about several issues concerning the Asian country. The U.S. Northeast is recovering from its first Nor'easter of the season. And facial recognition finds a growing role in airport security despite the concerns of privacy advocates.

videoTitle: A Severe Fuel Shortage | October 27, 2021
videoDescription: A severe fuel shortage only adds to the chaos and instability in Haiti; today's show explains its causes. New technological efforts are being made to more efficiently map the ocean floor. And a CNN correspondent in England demonstrates how you can trot out turkeys for a live report -- and even make them do a trick!

videoTitle: An Apparent Military Coup | October 26, 2021
videoDescription: An apparent military coup in Sudan leads off our show this Tuesday. It's followed by a quick recap of weather-related events across America, from landslides in the West to suspected tornadoes in the Midwest. Finally, we're climbing into the Andes Mountains to see how thousands of potato varieties are preserved.

videoTitle: Dramatic Weather In The U.S. | October 25, 2021
videoDescription: A week of potentially dramatic weather descends on the United States. What appears to be a failed Russian satellite streaks across the night sky. A toy store owner explains how supply chain problems have created uncertainty for her business. And fishermen near a Spanish territory haul in a massive sunfish.

videoTitle: How Much Will Americans Spend On Halloween? | October 22, 2021
videoDescription: The up-and-down case numbers of Covid-19 -- in the U.S. and abroad -- are the subject of our first report this Friday. Then, we're examining how much money Americans are planning to spend on Halloween. A remarkable student-athlete in Georgia and a floating house in Canada wrap up our coverage for the week!

videoTitle: Missionaries In Haiti | October 21, 2021
videoDescription: The kidnapping of a group of American missionaries in Haiti draws attention to the nation's deteriorating security situation. A rare "megapod" of humpback whales is encountered near Australia. A new railway connects China and Laos. And an American performer is unexpectedly greeted by an American "Legend."

videoTitle: Drivers Versus Bicyclists | October 20, 2021
videoDescription: A toy company that sells slot cars is a microcosm of how supply chain disruptions are affecting U.S. businesses. In the capital of France, a struggle for space pits drivers against bicyclists. And off the coast of Israel, a diver discovers a sword dating back to the Crusades.

videoTitle: A New Space Race? | October 19, 2021
videoDescription: Family members, politicians, historians and civil rights advocates remember former U.S. Secretary of State Colin Powell. A new chapter in a "21st Century Space Race" develops as China advances its space station program. A company aims high in its efforts to produce an electric flying taxi. And professional artists help put on an amazing display of pumpkins.

videoTitle: "Traffic Jam" Piles Up | October 15, 2021
videoDescription: It's not just in California: A "traffic jam" of cargo piles up on the U.S. East Coast as well, and we're reporting on what's said to be the weakest link in the global supply chain. Meanwhile, workers in Italy use bacteria in an effort to preserve the nation's historic artifacts. And some serious Star Wars fans in Russia build their own X-Wing.

videoTitle: Gas Prices Are Going Up | October 13, 2021
videoDescription: Gas prices are high and expected to get higher in the U.S., and today's show explains many of the factors involved. A team of astronauts is simulating Mars life in Israel's Negev desert. A CNN Hero is helping other amputees get customized prosthetic devices. And a European man builds a home that always has the best view.

videoTitle: Thousands OF Flights Cancelled | October 12, 2021
videoDescription: Growing tensions between China and Taiwan pose a unique challenge for the United States. Thousands of flight cancellations lead to more questions for a U.S. carrier, and some passengers don't like the answers they've received. And a unique balloon festival takes flight in New Mexico.

videoTitle: Mail Delivery By Drone? | October 11, 2021
videoDescription: Coverage of the latest U.S. jobs report leads off our Monday edition of CNN 10. Why was it disappointing, and what might be some of the reasons behind it? The U.K. Royal Mail Service is testing out drone flights to a Scottish island. And the selfless gesture of a Mississippi homecoming queen wins recognition across America.

videoTitle: Touring The Supply-Chain Traffic Jam | October 8, 2021
videoDescription: Today's show begins in the air over Southern California, where we bring you a detailed illustration of how supply chain problems stretch from the ocean to a local taqueria. From there, we're headed to China, where ruins of a Great Wall fort were recently unearthed. And we're reporting on a whale of a rescue in Argentina.

videoTitle: Island Tensions And Travel By Hovercraft | October 7, 2021
videoDescription: Islands are at the center of our coverage this Thursday. Tensions between China and Taiwan start things off, and we're explaining how the United States factors in. Then, we're sailing back in time aboard a vehicle whose golden age is long past, though it still has a role in part of Europe.

videoTitle: Former Facebook Employee Testifies | October 6, 2021
videoDescription: A former Facebook employee testifies on Capitol Hill: Why does she criticize the company, and how does it respond? A transportation company hopes its suspended hubs will one day move people and cargo around cities. And a pair of Russian filmmakers arrive on the ISS for its first role as a feature film set.

videoTitle: An Oil Leak & A Recycling Effort | October 5, 2021
videoDescription: An oil leak off the coast of California triggers beach closings and a large cleanup effort, but officials don't yet know the cause. As efforts to deal with U.S. waste grow in number and usage, a recycling company is focusing on the electronics we throw away. And to raise money for college, an Alaska teenager turns an old truck into a mobile coffee shop.

videoTitle: A School Vaccine Mandate | October 4, 2021
videoDescription: Our week begins with an explanation of a controversial new law requiring millions of California students to get a Covid vaccine. Worsening energy shortages trigger several problems in China. The U.S. Supreme Court kicks off a new (and closely-watched) session. And an Oreo hits eBay with a $10,000 price tag.

videoTitle: Will There Be Shortages For Christmas? | October 1, 2021
videoDescription: As bottlenecks obstruct the international supply chain of goods, what do industry leaders say must happen to help relieve the situation? As the FCC ramps up its fight against robocalls, we're telling you why they're so hard to prevent. And as Instagram pauses its plans to create a platform for children, we're talking to older teens about the role of social media in their lives.

videoTitle: What Is Inflation? | September 30, 2021
videoDescription: Concerns over inflation lead off today's edition of our show. Afterward, we're taking a look at a NASA mission to study a swarm of asteroids in the same orbit as Jupiter. Back on Earth, conservationists in São Tomé and Príncipe work to end the controversial practice of "bee burning."

videoTitle: Top Military Officials Testify | September 29, 2021
videoDescription: Top U.S. military officials testify before Congress for the first time since the troubled U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan. We take a walk through the towering wax palm trees of Colombia. Drone sailboats are deployed in an effort to better understand hurricanes. And a squirrel stores its winter cache in a man's pickup truck.

videoTitle: New Look At An Erupting Volcano | September 27, 2021
videoDescription: We're returning to the Canary Islands today for a new look at a continually erupting volcano that's prompting thousands of evacuations. Afterward, we're introducing you to a CNN Hero who's helping bring electricity and sanitation to rural areas of Colombia

videoTitle: The General Debate Kicks Off | September 22, 2021
videoDescription: The General Debate kicks off at the 76th meeting of the United Nations General Assembly. Economic challenges deepen for some U.S. restaurants and retail establishments. And when a dog walks away from a live shot and takes a reporter along, the journalist makes a smooth recovery.

videoTitle: All About Science And Nature | September 21, 2021
videoDescription: Today's show is all about science and nature.  Our stories range from a volcanic eruption in the Canary Islands to some efforts to protect a fascinating fish.

videoTitle: An Apology From The U.S. Military | September 20, 2021
videoDescription: Today, we're explaining why U.S. military officials are apologizing for a "horrible mistake." We're exploring some of the reasons behind a new migrant surge along the U.S.-Mexico border. We're updating you on the completion of the first all-civilian spaceflight. And we're examining why the Arc de Triomphe has been all wrapped up.

videoTitle: Australia Acquires Nuclear Submarines | September 17, 2021
videoDescription: Geopolitics factor into today's show, as China speaks out against a new partnership between Australia, the United Kingdom, and the United States. The first all-civilian spaceflight is now orbiting Earth, but it came at a high cost. And a new skyscraper offers some incredible and unique views of New York City.

videoTitle: Hunting Murder Hornets | September 16, 2021
videoDescription: Agriculture officials hunt for murder hornets, a U.S. labor shortage causes challenges for the fishing industry, and we take a ride on a zero-gravity flight.

videoTitle: The Vaccine Mandate Debate | September 15, 2021
videoDescription: Should the U.S. government require American workers to be vaccinated? A down-the-middle look at that debate is our first story this Wednesday. We cover scientific efforts to "bring back" the woolly mammoth and restore the ocean floor near Hong Kong. And we show you who eats the giant vegetables left over from the Alaska State Fair.

videoTitle: Taking A Walk In Space | September 13, 2021
videoDescription: Today's show begins with a look at some of this year's September 11 memorial ceremonies, which were held exactly 20 years after the terrorist attacks took place. Afterward, we're taking a walk in space and talking to an astronaut to see exactly what it's like to work in orbit. And we're showing you how a space balloon could take passengers up, up and away.

videoTitle: Going Inside CIA Headquarters | September 9, 2021
videoDescription: China puts new restrictions on private businesses and private citizens, as the nation's communist government looks to increase its influence. As the 20th anniversary of the September 11 terrorist attacks approaches, we're taking you inside a museum at the CIA headquarters. And film colorization brings a new look at an extinct species from Australia.

videoTitle: Checking Out The Giant Sequoia Trees | September 3, 2021
videoDescription: Hurricane Ida's remnants flood parts of the U.S. Northeast, we assess the status of California's giant sequoias, and we measure a towering sandcastle.

videoTitle: A Drone's Eye View | September 2, 2021
videoDescription: Today's show examines the impact of Hurricane Ida, from the destruction it left to the challenges it created for many residents of Louisiana and Mississippi. Afterward, we're looking at the ways in which drones have changed the media landscape. And we're showing you how it recently rained dogs at a Canadian weather station.

videoTitle: Last Flight Out Of Afghanistan | September 1, 2021
videoDescription: In Afghanistan, the last U.S. military flight has departed. What's next for the unstable Asian country? In California, wildfires and drought combine to threaten homes. In China, the government strictly limits online gaming for minors. And in space, astronauts hold a floating pizza party.

videoTitle: Rescues And Recoveries | August 31, 2021
videoDescription: With rescues and recovery assessments under way in Louisiana and Mississippi, CNN 10 is giving you a sense of the damage wrought by Hurricane Ida. With a new type of cooling system available for buildings, some businesses that can afford the equipment are seeing benefits. And with a relatively new baby at the Columbus Zoo, visitors are lining up to see a "trunk show."

videoTitle: Explaining Rapid Hurricane Intensification | August 30, 2021
videoDescription: A major hurricane has made landfall in Louisiana on the 16th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina. The U.S. military has carried out an airstrike in Afghanistan targeting a suspected terrorist. A CNN Hero helps provide hygiene products to people in need. And a golden retriever retrieves the TSA's award for cutest dog.

videoTitle: Attack At The Afghan Airport | August 27, 2021
videoDescription: A terrorist attack in Afghanistan, a high-speed concept train, a CNN Hero's work to feed the hungry, and a dive into the deepest pool are today's topics.

videoTitle: The Complicated Issue Of Evictions | August 26, 2021
videoDescription: Today's show covers evictions in the United States, the impact of the Census on U.S. House representation, and the booming business of "fake space dirt."

videoTitle: Variants, Flash Flooding, And A Strange Pizza | August 25, 2021
videoDescription: The Covid pandemic is our first topic today: We're discussing the Delta variant, a formal vaccine approval, controversies concerning mandates, and the virus' impact on global shipping. We're also reporting on deadly flooding in Middle Tennessee and the general dangers posed by flash floods. And a feature on a controversial type of pizza invites a hungry debate.

videoTitle: Filming Movies In Space | August 23, 2021
videoDescription: On August 23rd, CNN 10 is kicking off its first show of the season! We're giving you a quick preview of some of the stories we'll be covering this week, and we're featuring a report on the landfall of Tropical Storm Henri in Rhode Island. Today's other topics include filming movies in space and some funny fails of humanoid robots.

videoTitle: The Origin Of Memorial Day | May 28, 2021
videoDescription: Our last show of the season covers the significance and origin of Memorial Day, the anniversary of an outbreak of racial violence in Oklahoma, the history and challenges of walking in space, and the reintroduction of a carnivorous marsupial to the Australian mainland. Thank you so much for watching!

videoTitle: A Deeper Look At The Lab Leak Theory | May 27, 2021
videoDescription: More international experts are calling for a deeper look into the "lab leak theory" when it comes to the mysterious origin of coronavirus. A super flower blood moon makes global headlines when it appears in the sky. And we take you into the Virunga Mountains to see how veterinarians are helping conserve mountain gorillas.

videoTitle: Dogs Show They Can Detect A Virus | May 26, 2021
videoDescription: A high-ranking U.S. government official visits the Middle East following a recent ceasefire. The U.S. warns tourists to avoid Japan, though the Olympics are moving ahead. Dogs and bees are being studied for their potential role in detecting Covid in humans. And a leaked video appears to show a UFO as seen from a U.S. Navy ship.

videoTitle: A Trip To The Arctic | May 25, 2021
videoDescription: Today's show starts in the Arctic, where Russia is building up its military presence and raising concerns about regional dominance. From there, we're featuring a pair of stories from Africa: One centers on a volcanic eruption, and the other covers a wildlife census. A record-setting diamond rounds out our coverage.

videoTitle: 10 Years After A Tornado | May 24, 2021
videoDescription: A U.S. community celebrates its rebirth 10 years after suffering a devastating tornado. China lands its own rover on Mars. A CNN Hero helps former inmates become established in successful fitness careers. And researchers employ a computer simulation to animate how a star is born.

videoTitle: Global Inflation Fears | May 20, 2021
videoDescription: On a border between Morocco and a Spanish city, thousands of migrants suddenly attempt to enter the European Union. In the southern U.S., heavy rains trigger flash flood warnings in several states. Globally, inflation fears drive down international markets. And a famous arch collapses in the Galapagos Islands.

videoTitle: The Eventual Return To Normalcy | May 19, 2021
videoDescription: The eventual return of normalcy is today's first topic: How could it be a challenging transition for those who've become used to relative isolation? We're explaining how a major media deal reflects changes in the industry. And we're reporting on an exotic car manufacturer's decision to offer only hybrids in the years ahead.

videoTitle: Why Is The Golden Gate Bridge Singing? | May 18, 2021
videoDescription: Violence in the Middle East and a cyclone's landfall in India headline our show this Tuesday. We're unraveling the mystery of a tonal, "singing" sound at San Francisco's Golden Gate Bridge. And we're showing you how two New York City police officers brought a wayward family of ducks back to Central Park.

videoTitle: Masks Or No Masks? | May 17, 2021
videoDescription: The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has issued new guidance concerning face masks and social distancing, but it's causing confusion and controversy in some areas. Japan is moving ahead with plans to host the Olympics, but some people there are calling for a cancellation of the Games. And 3D printing is being tested as means of building low-cost houses.

videoTitle: What Is The West Bank And Why Is It Important? | May 14, 2021
videoDescription: Amid unrest in the Holy Land, we're exploring the roots of the recent clashes between Israelis and Palestinians. We're also reporting on the restart of a pipeline whose shutdown caused severe disruptions in gas deliveries to the U.S. Southeast. And we're taking flight on a concept plane that could speed up water travel at low altitude.

videoTitle: A Look At Gasoline Shortages | May 13, 2021
videoDescription: Today's show starts with an explanation of the worst violence in years between Israelis and Palestinians. It's followed by a look at the U.S. gasoline shortages related to a cyberattack. The "trashy" work of an award-winning architect and a see-through elevator wrap up our program.

videoTitle: A Cyberattack On A Pipeline | May 11, 2021
videoDescription: A cyberattack on America's largest fuel pipeline is today's first story: How could this affect fuel prices? We're bringing you a tale of two districts to illustrate two very different approaches when it comes to schools reopening. And we're explaining why this year's Kentucky Derby winner may not be able to compete in the other Triple Crown races.

videoTitle: A Rare Cicada Emergence | May 10, 2021
videoDescription: Today's show gets you up to speed on what went down this weekend with regard to a runaway rocket. That's followed by a snapshot of the U.S. labor market in the wake of a disappointing report concerning jobs and unemployment. A rare cicada emergence and the reasons behind it round out our coverage this Monday.

videoTitle: Catching Up With A CNN Hero | May 7, 2021
videoDescription: After a controversial opinion on carrot cake, today's show delves into three international headlines concerning Covid-19. Then, we're catching up with a 2014 CNN Hero who has expanded her program to help students through creative self-expression. A gourmet menu that's gone to the dogs is our last story this Friday.

videoTitle: Companies Struggling To Fill Jobs | May 5, 2021
videoDescription: Despite a growing number of jobs in manufacturing, U.S. companies are struggling to fill their available positions. Meantime, tensions in the Black Sea are inflamed between Russia and Ukraine. A jet suit is being tested by the British Royal Navy and Royal Marines. And a record-setting bridge is raising suspense in Portugal.

videoTitle: Shortage Of Gasoline? | April 30, 2021
videoDescription: Japan has released new rules for Olympians, as the Games approach amid controversy and concerns about coronavirus. We explain how a shortage of truck drivers could result in a shortage of gasoline. China has successfully launched a new module for its new space station. And wildlife causes an internet outage in part of Canada.

videoTitle: How Many People In The United States? | April 28, 2021
videoDescription: U.S. Census results and how they could impact the House of Representatives compose our first topic this Wednesday. A shortage of workers complicates the recovery for restaurants that survived last year's mandatory closures. U.S. lumber prices go through the roof. And we have a look at the first test event of the upcoming Olympics.

videoTitle: A Short Ride On The Hyperloop | April 27, 2021
videoDescription: A new wave of coronavirus cases has risen in India, and we're explaining what the country needs and why officials are telling people not to panic. Then, we're exploring the significance of the U.S. government's recognition of the Armenian genocide. And we're taking a short ride aboard the Hyperloop, though its future is uncertain.

videoTitle: Radioactive Water In The Pacific | April 22, 2021
videoDescription: Today's first story centers on Japan's controversial plan to treat and release radioactive water into the Pacific. From there, we're taking you to central Africa, where uncertainty hangs over the nation of Chad. An investigation involving an electric carmaker and the advent of "travel bubbles" are also featured this Thursday.

videoTitle: Surfaces, A Verdict, And A View From A Wolf | April 21, 2021
videoDescription: New medical suggestions concerning surfaces, disinfectants and coronavirus are outlined today on CNN 10. After that, we're covering the verdict in a former police officer's widely watched trial. A drone's helicopter's first flight on Mars and a camera attached to a wolf round out our coverage.

videoTitle: What Is Inflation? | April 20, 2021
videoDescription: What is inflation, and why are some U.S. economists concerned about it? How much has Covid impacted the airline industry, and what are some signs that it's recovering? And what kind of environmental challenges are being caused by used personal protective equipment? All of these questions are explored today on CNN 10.

videoTitle: Why Go To Mars? | April 19, 2021
videoDescription: Three of the questions explored this Monday on CNN 10: What is the initial forecast for the 2021 Atlantic hurricane season? Why do scientists continue the difficult and expensive work of exploring Mars? Why did the sheep cross the road in Idaho, and why did the event draw a crowd? We hope you enjoy the show!

videoTitle: Music By Spiders? | April 16, 2021
videoDescription: Today's show covers the new U.S. sanctions on Russia: Why are they being imposed, and how is the Asian country responding to the accusations? That's followed by a report on a CNN Hero who's helping fellow amputees. Spider music and penguin recovery are our two other topics this Friday.

videoTitle: A Major Troop Announcement | April 15, 2021
videoDescription: A major announcement concerning U.S. troops in Afghanistan headlines today's edition of CNN 10. After that, we're detailing a new discovery in an ancient land, and we're exploring an effort in India to help people and wildlife live more harmoniously. Finally, we're discussing a robot that serves meals on wheels.

videoTitle: Headlines In The U.S. And Beyond | April 14, 2021
videoDescription: Today's show discusses recent events in Minnesota related to a shooting involving a police officer and a civilian. Afterward, we're exploring tensions between China and Taiwan -- and how the United States factors in. And we're introducing you to a chihuahua with a relatively small pool of potential owners.

videoTitle: A View Of A "Pink Moon" | April 12, 2021
videoDescription: This Monday's show is all about nature and science. First, we're covering the eruption of a volcano in St. Vincent and the Grenadines. Then, we're off to an asteroid for an update on a U.S. mission there. A view of a "Pink Moon" and recap of a recent waterspout wrap up today's edition of CNN 10.

videoTitle: The Vaccine Passport Debate | April 9, 2021
videoDescription: An explanation of vaccine passports and the controversy surrounding them is our first topic today on CNN 10. That's followed by what's being described as a shortage of ketchup packets in America. And before we roll into the weekend, we're taking you on a coaster that's destined to be a record-breaker.

videoTitle: A Parade Of Mummies? | April 6, 2021
videoDescription: Jobs in America: What are the latest numbers from the U.S. Labor Department, and how do they compare to pre-pandemic levels? That's our first topic today, followed by a report on how cases of Covid-19 are impacting the nation of India. A parade of mummies in Egypt and a 121-year-old chocolate bar are also featured.

videoTitle: Is Amazon A Monopoly? | April 5, 2021
videoDescription: A special edition of CNN 10 focuses on Amazon, the $1 trillion U.S. company that has changed the retail landscape. We'll explore some of the technology it uses, the challenges it has faced and created, the concerns about whether it's a monopoly, and the profits it has generated.

videoTitle: A World Of Augmented Reality | April 2, 2021
videoDescription: This Friday on CNN 10, we're having a look at augmented and mixed reality and exploring some of its applications for the military and the workforce. A new season of Major League Baseball has begun, and we're examining what that looks like in terms of fans in the stands. And we're detailing some new designs that could adorn the aircraft cabin of the future.

videoTitle: A University's Vaccine Plan | March 30, 2021
videoDescription: A U.S. university will soon require Covid-19 vaccinations for students on campus. Parts of middle Tennessee are struggling to recover from deadly flash floods. A CNN Hero helps displaced and orphaned children in Nigeria. And a robot's self-portrait fetches hundreds of thousands at auction.

videoTitle: New Voting Laws | March 29, 2021
videoDescription: The U.S. state of Georgia has passed new voting laws, and there’s a partisan divide over the action. A massive cargo ship continues to block maritime traffic in the Suez Canal, and costs are skyrocketing for the global shipping industry. And almost two years after the roof of a medieval cathedral caught fire, rebuilding efforts are under way.

videoTitle: First Flight On Mars | March 26, 2021
videoDescription: A futuristic drone helicopter on Mars is carrying a piece of human history, and we'll tell you how the past and present are taking flight. The weather systems that flooded part of Australia have moved out to sea, but they've left a changed landscape behind them. And a conservationist in Brazil is looking to reconnect fragments of a rainforest that's a fraction of its former size.

videoTitle: Suez Canal Traffic Jam | March 25, 2021
videoDescription: A traffic jam in the Suez Canal leads off today's show, as we explore the impact of a damaged cargo ship and the history of the canal itself. Afterward, we're examining an effort to cut down on the plastic waste generated from getting take-out. And we're lending our ears to a program that literally soothes the savage beast.

videoTitle: A Shortage Of Computer Chips | March 24, 2021
videoDescription: In another side-effect of the Covid-19 pandemic, a shortage of computer chips threatens to hamper the production of cars and trucks. During a volcanic eruption in Iceland, onlookers get an up-close look at the lava. And at a hospital in Massachusetts, a robot dog with the face of a doctor makes the rounds.

videoTitle: Record-Breaking Flood | March 23, 2021
videoDescription: A state in Australia that's still recovering from record-breaking bushfires is now struggling with record-breaking flooding. A demonstration mission with the ultimate goal of cleaning up space junk is taking place over our heads. And an ancient, gold mask is discovered in China along with a trove of other relics.

videoTitle: Major Olympic Announcement | March 22, 2021
videoDescription: Olympic organizers make a major announcement concerning the 2020 Tokyo Summer Games. A CNN Hero finds a way to connect with students who share his struggles with traditional learning. And a long-lost surfboard finally finds its way back to its owner, years after it disappeared into the waves.

videoTitle: Identifying An Interstellar Object | March 19, 2021
videoDescription: The U.S. House of Representatives holds a hearing on discrimination and violence against Asian-Americans. Researchers work to identify an "interstellar object" that passed through our solar system in 2017. We take a trip on the Overseas Highway through the Florida Keys. And a robotic assistant helps people virtually tour an art gallery.

videoTitle: Antibodies: How They Work | March 18, 2021
videoDescription: Antibodies: what they are, how they work, and what they have to do with coronavirus all factor into our first story this Thursday. With the American South facing the threat of tornadoes, we're explaining what La Niña may have to do with it. And a new discovery concerning the Dead Sea Scrolls makes headlines from the Middle East.

videoTitle: Declining College Enrollment | March 17, 2021
videoDescription: Today's show explores the issue of declining college enrollment in the United States, though the decrease is not spread evenly across all schools. We're examining the impact of Covid-related closures on Broadway, which hasn’t seen a year-long shutdown for centuries. And we're bringing you scenes from a historic snowstorm in the American West.

videoTitle: Spring Break Has Sprung | March 15, 2021
videoDescription: Spring break has sprung at many schools across the U.S. We're reporting on the different ways the event is (and isn't) being observed in the era of coronavirus. Afterward, we're introducing you to a CNN Hero who is helping others overcome adversity after doing so himself. And we're showing you a life-sized replica of a Star Wars ship.

videoTitle: Battle For Space Supremacy | March 12, 2021
videoDescription: With China and Russia teaming up to work on a new space station, will the alliance lead to an era of cooperation or competition? After that report, we're examining an effort to form a tree-lined border to the Sahara Desert. And we're telling you what it would take to buy your very own Bahamian island.

videoTitle: The Cost Of Living Under The Ocean | March 10, 2021
videoDescription: New coronavirus treatments headline today's show, as the U.S. government issues new guidelines for people who've received a Covid vaccine. Then, we're going on an underwater adventure to explore sea stations and sea slugs. Finally, a snake slithers onto the scene with markings that are making people smile.

videoTitle: A New Stimulus Plan | March 9, 2021
videoDescription: A new stimulus plan makes its way through the U.S. Congress. Cultural scars remain from the Taliban, 20 years after they ruled Afghanistan. A CNN Hero continues her work to save harbor seals. And new technology is used to "read" the contents of letters that were locked centuries ago.

videoTitle: A Swarm Of Thousands Of Earthquakes | March 5, 2021
videoDescription: A European nation is on guard against a possible volcanic eruption following a swarm of thousands of earthquakes. An experimental Mars rocket makes a difficult landing but explodes shortly afterward. A U.S. state considers joining two others in ignoring civil time changes. And a crossing guard doesn't let age get in her way of helping people.

videoTitle: Froot Loops Pizza? | March 3, 2021
videoDescription: Experts say that new satellite images suggest that North Korea may be trying to conceal part of its controversial nuclear program. The discovery of a four-wheeled chariot suggests that Pompeii might have had a type of luxury limo service. And the advent of Froot Loops pizza suggests that dessert isn't limited to one specific mealtime.

videoTitle: If Tigers Could Sing | February 26, 2021
videoDescription: A "singing tiger" and bad poetry are two things you'll hear this Friday on CNN 10! We're also covering a fireball sighting in Canada, the recovery of a species in Europe, and another sign that the 2020 Tokyo Olympics will indeed go on.

videoTitle: Rise Of The Rats? February 25, 2021
videoDescription: International tensions over an international nuclear deal compose our first topic this Thursday. And after a report on a continued eruption of a famous volcano, we're examining how a Covid-related lockdown has given rise to rats in London. For dessert, find out how some pastry chefs in Denver are turning famous cookies into gourmet delicacies.

videoTitle: A Photographic Mystery Explained | February 24, 2021
videoDescription: A standoff between Facebook and the Australian government has calmed down, and news is returning to the media site. A mysterious message scrawled on a famous painting appears to have been solved. A photographic mystery is partially explained by some of the people in the 60-year-old slides. And a couple builds a [really] tiny home during the coronavirus pandemic.

videoTitle: The Costs Of Space Travel | February 23, 2021
videoDescription: Certain Boeing planes with a certain Pratt and Whitney engine have been grounded following an unnerving incident over Colorado. After explaining that story, we're bringing you a snapshot of coronavirus headlines from three countries. And as NASA looks to open the ISS to more commercial visits, we're exploring some of the costs of space travel.

videoTitle: A Chicken Goes Sledding | February 22, 2021
videoDescription: It's absolutely true that a sledding chicken is featured on today's show; it rates a perfect 10/10. Before we get to that, though, we're reporting on the water shortage in Texas and the first pictures from a newly landed Mars rover. An explanation of how important work continues at the Louvre (even while it's closed) is another story covered this Monday!

videoTitle: Landing On Mars | February 19, 2021
videoDescription: After more than six months of space travel, a new NASA mission arrives at Mars, but getting the landing right is the hard part. As a blast of Arctic air finally moves away from the U.S., we're explaining ice jams, ice pancakes and ice volcanoes. And speaking of volcanoes, Italy's Mt. Etna puts on a fireworks show for Sicily.

videoTitle: Mysterious Crater Appears | February 18, 2021
videoDescription: The U.S. state of Texas is still seeing widespread power outages, as a one-two punch of winter storms rakes across the central and eastern U.S. Mysterious craters appear in Siberia, and scientists discuss how they formed in the barren landscape. And we dive into the deep blue sea to explain how an ocean advocacy group obtains its 3-D, virtual reality footage.

videoTitle: A New Model On Plate Tectonics | February 17, 2021
videoDescription: As a winter storm scrapes across the U.S., some widespread power outages leave millions of Americans in the cold. A new computer model on plate tectonics aims to help geologists better understand the Earth. Artificial intelligence brings assistance and controversy to some online classrooms. And an artist creates what's likely the biggest doodle on record.

videoTitle: A Virtual Field Trip To Iceland | February 16, 2021
videoDescription: An American impeachment trial comes to an end, as an American winter storm rakes across the country. Covid numbers drop in the U.S., as the search for the origins of the disease continues. We take a virtual field trip to Iceland. And we introduce you to a border collie that just became a millionaire several times over.

videoTitle: A Test To Fly? | February 11, 2021
videoDescription: The U.S. government considers mandatory Covid testing for all domestic flight passengers, as some industry leaders object. A conservationist works to protect the unique natural features of the Sierra Gorda ecological region. And when a lawyer shows up to a virtual courtroom meeting, cat's got his tongue.

videoTitle: What Happens To All Those Returns? | February 10, 2021
videoDescription: A change in economic policy is coming to the communist nation of Cuba, and we're explaining its significance today on CNN 10. The rise of online shopping has brought a rise in package returns, and we're exploring how retailers are dealing with them. And a New Yorker continues his tradition of amazing his community with elaborate snow sculptures.

videoTitle: Below Freezing In All 50 States | February 4, 2021
videoDescription: Meteorologists say the polar vortex can't technically "come and get you," but it's sure going to feel like it in North America this weekend. After a report on that, we're covering some of the nuanced approaches to education in the time of coronavirus. And we're taking you on a virtual field trip to Banff National Park.

videoTitle: No Matter What | February 3, 2021
videoDescription: Japanese government officials say the 2020 Tokyo Olympics will be held no matter what, but a U.S. state is throwing its hat in the ring as a possible host. Meanwhile, two astronauts take a walk outside the ISS, and efforts are underway in China to save the golden snub-nosed monkey. Finally, a pair of climbers in Slovenia tackle an incredibly tall tower.

videoTitle: The Biggest Fish In The Sea | February 2, 2021
videoDescription: A nation in the midst of a coup is our first destination this Tuesday. We're explaining the latest events in Myanmar (Burma) and how they factor into a series of historic troubles for the country. From there, we're taking a swim with the biggest fish in the sea. And we're showing you what pandas do when their habitat is covered in snow.

videoTitle: Previewing The Hyperloop | February 1, 2021
videoDescription: Monday's show begins with an explanation of a new mask mandate by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control. Afterward, we're giving you a preview of Hyperloop technology, though it hasn't gotten off the ground yet. Reports on winter weather and Groundhog Day conclude our coverage.

videoTitle: Touching Down On Mars | January 29, 2021
videoDescription: The U.S. gross domestic product shrank from 2019 to 2020 as a result of the coronavirus pandemic. Today's show has details on the change and the silver lining. Meanwhile, a new rover is just weeks away from touching down on Mars. And surf's up at Hawaii's Banzai Pipeline; we're taking you there for a ride on the waves.

videoTitle: A New Theory About Dogs? | January 27, 2021
videoDescription: Officials assess the damage from severe weather in Alabama. Reporters update some international responses to the coronavirus pandemic. A new study brings new theories on dog migration and domestication. And we examine the legacy of U.S. "first pets."

videoTitle: The Changing World Of Travel | January 26, 2021
videoDescription: Today's first topic on CNN 10: the schedule of the U.S. Senate with regard to an upcoming impeachment trial. That's followed by reports on the changing travel industry and a new discovery in Egypt. The sleep habits of bees and an illuminated ice palace conclude our coverage this Tuesday.

videoTitle: One Year After Wuhan | January 25, 2021
videoDescription: One year after Wuhan, China was locked down during its coronavirus outbreak, a CNN reporter returns to the city he once rushed to leave. Six months before the scheduled start of the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, questions are being raised about whether the Games will go on. And months after wildfires raged through parts of Colorado, a count of elk herds yields some good news.

videoTitle: The Moon Gets A New Law | January 22, 2021
videoDescription: We have a lot of ground to cover this Friday. From the busy schedule of the U.S. Senate to a new law concerning space, we're reporting on news from the Earth to the moon. Lake-effect snow, a virtual visit to Kenya, and a man's mission to return long-lost class rings are our other topics.

videoTitle: Remembering A Civil Rights Leader | January 15, 2021
videoDescription: As we approach the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday, CNN 10 is looking back at the civil rights leader's work and listening to some young voices read his speeches. Also featured: Initial jobless claims give a negative indication about the health of the U.S. economy, but there is a silver lining. And a new robot aims to give people a hand with the dishes.

videoTitle: As Inauguration Day Approaches | January 13, 2021
videoDescription: Challenges and changes characterize the rollout of coronavirus vaccines in the U.S. The FBI says it's working to prevent violence as Inauguration Day approaches. The Consumer Electronics show goes virtual for the first time. And augmented reality is being test-driven in some vehicles.

videoTitle: What's Next? | January 11, 2021
videoDescription: First today: a report on new political developments related to last Wednesday's events in Washington, D.C. Then, we're updating you on the latest scientific observations concerning Covid-19. A power outage in Pakistan and an unstable polar vortex are our next two topics. And we're wrapping up with a 91-year-old’s reaction to a unique tribute.

videoTitle: Back WITH The Future | January 8, 2021
videoDescription: The congressional certification of Electoral College votes is our first subject this Friday. Afterward, we're giving you a glimpse of international governments' latest Covid-19 plans. And we're showing you how virtual reality is helping some South Koreans take a digital step back in time.

videoTitle: Trouble On Capitol Hill | January 7, 2021
videoDescription: Leading off Thursday's show: trouble on Capitol Hill. We'll objectively explain what happened and follow it with an update on U.S. Senate projections from Georgia. Afterward, we're examining the potential for artificial intelligence in the recycling collection business. And we're showing you a smartphone that can fly.

videoTitle: The Future Of The Movie Theater | January 6, 2021
videoDescription: Tensions between the U.S. and Iran headline today's show. We're also interviewing an executive about the future of movie theaters, which have been a fixture of American society since they were known as nickelodeons. And we're showing you a creative way in which rescuers are using dogs to get people's attention about snow dangers.

videoTitle: All Eyes On Georgia | January 5, 2021
videoDescription: Today's edition of CNN 10 begins by exploring the significance of Tuesday's election in Georgia. That's followed by a bit of trivia and an explanation of how the coronavirus pandemic is once again threatening the Summer Olympics. And we're taking a seat at an ancient "snack bar" in the ruined city of Pompeii.

videoTitle: 2021 Begins | January 4, 2021
videoDescription: Welcome back to CNN 10! Our first show of 2021 kicks off with a report involving stimulus, vaccines, and one of the major challenges of the previous year. Then, we're taking a look at the rocketing value of Bitcoin and the rise of the technology behind it. And if you've ever danced "the Robot" and wondered if robots could dance "the Human" (and even if you haven't), we have an entertaining exhibition to wrap up the show!

videoTitle: Looking Back At 2020 | December 18, 2020
videoDescription:
On our last show of 2020, we're taking a look back at some of the biggest events to make headlines this year. Afterward, we're giving you a bit of music trivia before exploring the scientific definition of a white Christmas. And we're showing you how one 18-year-old decked his car with lights of festivity.

CNN 10 is grateful to have served you throughout this challenging year! We look forward to seeing you again on Monday, January 4.

videoTitle: That's A Lot Of Snow | December 16, 2020
videoDescription: With differing levels of infections, Japan, France, Britain and South Korea institute different measures concerning coronavirus. Forecasters say a major storm is taking shape for the U.S. Northeast. And after an update on the Hubble Space Telescope, we're reporting on a mineral that could improve the efficiency of solar panels.

videoTitle: Voting In The U.S. Electoral College | December 15, 2020
videoDescription: Voting in the U.S. Electoral College leads off today's edition of CNN 10. Then, we're examining news past and present: We take a look at some ancient rock paintings, and we consider the future of the office with so many people working from home. Finally, a "Santa school" helps St. Nicks brush up on their social distancing skills.

videoTitle: "Stuff" Now Outweighs Life On Earth? | December 14, 2020
videoDescription: Shipping is under way for a U.S. coronavirus vaccine, following its emergency use authorization from the FDA. A project is under way that apparently turns desert soil into fertile farmland, though it comes at a cost. And new research suggests that the things people have made now outweigh all the living things on Earth.

videoTitle: Solar 'Belch' Heading This Way | December 11, 2020
videoDescription: Two new lawsuits are targeting Facebook: What is the company accused of doing, and how is it responding? An unmanned SpaceX rocket has good launch but a crash landing. A solar "belch" is expected to trigger an exceptional light show. And we explain the phenomena of meteorological winters and atmospheric rivers.

videoTitle: Hitting The Slopes Of Europe | December 10, 2020
videoDescription: Today's show begins with more details about an upcoming runoff election in Georgia. Then, we're hitting the slopes of Europe to discuss some of the economic ripple effects of Covid closures. An extraordinary "pay it forward" event and a gigantic goldfish also make a splash on CNN 10.

videoTitle: Can We Agree On How Tall Everest Is? | December 9, 2020
videoDescription: Vaccine deliveries and restaurant deliveries are our first two subjects this Wednesday. The exact height of Mount Everest and the importance of regular exercise follow. And though it may be a challenge to judge, breakdancing is set to make its Olympic debut in Paris.

videoTitle: Facial-Recognition For Bears | December 2, 2020
videoDescription: A group of American medical advisers meets to determine what group will be the first to have access to a coronavirus vaccine. Researchers develop facial-recognition software for bears, and it carries a different kind of controversy than the type used for humans. And a mysterious monolith appears and disappears in the Utah desert.

videoTitle: Flying in 2021 Looks Like This? | December 1, 2020
videoDescription: Tensions flare in the Middle East following the apparent assassination of an Iranian nuclear scientist. Europeans prepare for the Christmas season, but the markets look very different this year. And an airline requires rapid Covid tests for passengers on certain flights, but is a vaccine requirement on the horizon?

videoTitle: Traffic On An Animal Highway | November 30, 2020
videoDescription: On this last day of November 2020, CNN 10 is rummaging through a mixed bag of indicators when it comes to shopping and the U.S. economy. We're also reporting on a female first for football and an "animal highway." And we're discussing how a pair of council candidates in Tennessee settled an electoral tie the old-fashioned way.

videoTitle: Thanksgiving And Beyond | November 24, 2020
videoDescription: On our second and last show of this holiday week, CNN 10 is reporting on some of the large stores that will be closed on Thanksgiving Day -- and some that hope they'll be allowed to stay open in the days that follow. The debate over contact tracing and personal QR codes follows. And we're setting sail with a story about a historic shipwreck that recently surfaced in Florida.

videoTitle: The Most Expensive Object Ever Built | November 23, 2020
videoDescription: CNN 10 is producing two shows this week. The first begins with holiday travel in the time of coronavirus. Then, we're making a trip to the most expensive object ever built to check in with its four newest arrivals. Our third story covers a show that shows off the innovations of graduate students.

videoTitle: A Driverless Future? | November 19, 2020
videoDescription: A special edition of CNN 10 is headed your way this Thursday! Though fully automated driving may be decades away, we're exploring what city roadways could look like if everything goes as hoped by the manufacturers and supporters of driverless technology. And we're considering how driverless cars could change the look of American cities themselves.

videoTitle: U.S. Troop Withdrawal | November 18, 2020
videoDescription: First up this Wednesday: the planned withdrawals of thousands of U.S. troops from Afghanistan and Iraq. Then, we're covering the topics of seasonal affective disorder, a major discovery in Egypt, and a new tool that could be used to help prevent overfishing. Baby Yoda's trip to the ISS is our last topic.

videoTitle: The History Of Ice Cream | November 17, 2020
videoDescription: Another vaccine from a U.S. drug company is showing promise against coronavirus. Why is this unprecedented, and how soon could these drugs become available? Another hurricane bears down on Central America, and it's the most powerful of the season. And after a bit of history concerning ice cream, we're examining how the present delivery of the confection continues to evolve.

videoTitle: A Tunnel Under Stonehenge | November 16, 2020
videoDescription: Today's down-the-middle coverage begins with a look at the projected balance of power in the U.S. Senate. Then, we're off to Stonehenge for a report on a controversial new traffic project. The planned launch of a NASA/SpaceX mission and an astronomical football score wrap up our show!

videoTitle: Diving To The Deepest Part Of The Ocean | November 12, 2020
videoDescription: A hospitalization record, the threat of more lockdowns, and a new antibody therapy: All of these topics are related to Covid-19, and they're all addressed at the beginning of today's show. Then, we're diving into a report about how China has just reached one of the deepest parts of the ocean. And we're showing you how technology is being utilized to put a New York arts center on the move.

videoTitle: Would You Travel In The Hyperloop? | November 11, 2020
videoDescription: After a quick recap of stories making headlines in the U.S., we're taking a seat aboard a Hyperloop test and having a look at the pros and cons of the new technology. Pet adoption in the Covid era is our next topic. And today's show wraps up with a homemade rollercoaster that strongly resembles a popular Disney ride.

videoTitle: Typhoons Vs. Hurricanes | October 29, 2020
videoDescription: This Thursday's show begins with news of two storms: a typhoon in Vietnam and a hurricane in the U.S. Afterward, we're looking at some of the new restrictions planned in Europe, as the spread of coronavirus speeds up. And we're taking you to a newly discovered coral reef off the coast of Australia.

videoTitle: Voting In America - Past And Present | October 28, 2020
videoDescription: Voting in America -- past and present -- is the focus of today's first report on CNN 10. We're exploring new theories about water on the moon and explaining how you can verify the news you read online. And we're having a little fun and games with a giant Pacman board meant to show off the construction industry.

videoTitle: A Promising Vaccine And Prescribed Fires | November 10, 2020
videoDescription: A U.S. pharmaceutical company says its coronavirus vaccine is showing promise, a storm hits the Florida Keys after causing destruction in Central America, and a Native American tribe uses and promotes prescribed burning as an effective means of controlling wildfires.

videoTitle: Election Day In America | November 3, 2020
videoDescription: On Election Day in America, we're explaining some of the possible complications with the voting process that could delay results beyond November 3. We're also examining whether the weather influences turnout. And after our discussion of Earth-bound events, we're lending an ear to the sounds of space.

videoTitle: Debating Another Lockdown | November 2, 2020
videoDescription: English lawmakers are debating another national lockdown. A deadly earthquake strikes Turkey and Greece. The U.S. gears up for Election Day. We explain a "morning daylight" advantage to falling back to standard time. And when a raccoon drops into a Texas school, fun ensues.

videoTitle: How Far From A Complete Recovery? | October 30, 2020
videoDescription: America's gross domestic product has set a record for growth, but how far is the country from a complete recovery? A fast-moving hurricane has raked the U.S. Southeast. A firefighting robot is hoped to reduce risks and save lives. And Nigeria's first female mechanic helps other women learn the trade. These stories and more are featured this Friday on CNN 10!

videoTitle: They Found A Murder Hornet Nest | October 26, 2020
videoDescription: Entomologists have vacuumed up a nest of murder hornets in Washington state. Seasonal winds are threatening to worsen wildfires in northern California. A CNN Hero is helping provide RVs to people who've lost their homes. And coronavirus is causing a number of changes to some Halloween celebrations.

videoTitle: Living Under The Sea | October 21, 2020
videoDescription: Why is the U.S. government suing the Google technology company? Today's show explains the answer and Google's response to the suit. Meanwhile, new technology is hoping ocean researchers live closer to the areas they want to study. And a retired toymaker's Halloween decorations would terrify Little Miss Muffet.

videoTitle: There's Cell Service On The Moon? | October 20, 2020
videoDescription: Two weeks from Election Day, CNN 10 is taking on the topic of the Electoral College and explaining how it works. That's followed by a look at how some European countries are addressing increasing numbers of coronavirus cases. And we're spending the rest of today's show in space, reporting on asteroids and a potential 4G network on the moon.

videoTitle: The Impact Of Music On The Mind | October 19, 2020
videoDescription: There's been a flare-up of violence between Armenia and Azerbaijan, and today's show is exploring why and explaining its international significance. We also take a look at how a CNN Hero is finding new ways to use music to help senior citizens during the coronavirus pandemic. And just what is the point of a scented protective mask? CNN 10 has the answer!

videoTitle: Is Space Too Crowded? | October 16, 2020
videoDescription: Coronavirus cases are on the rise in most U.S. states, and health officials are warning Americans to be more vigilant in the cooler months. Speaking of cooler months, a La Niña has formed in the Pacific, and meteorologists say it could affect the weather for months to come. Meantime, a crowded space environment is about to get more populated, and a "squidbot" could help scientists explore the sea.

videoTitle: The Balance of Power | October 15, 2020

videoTitle: A Look Inside the 9/11 Memorial Museum

videoTitle: See how experts measure glacier melt in Iceland

videoTitle: How to know what's happening in North Korea

videoTitle: Could Europe see a nuclear disaster? Hear what expert says

videoTitle: Air conditioning is bad for the planet. Here are some possible solutions

videoTitle: He was a famous hacker. Now, he's detailing his main concern with Twitter

videoTitle: The creature that can munch through plastic waste
videoDescription: Mealworms are a common food for livestock. They also happen to be able to eat several different types of plastic.

videoTitle: Is the Future of Farming Underground?

videoTitle: What are these beavers doing on the River Otter?

videoTitle: The all-female crew sailing the world to study plastic pollution
videoDescription: Emily Penn has studied marine plastic pollution for years. Then she discovered the issue may disproportionately affect women, so she put together an all-female crew to research the problem.

videoTitle: The benefits of swimming for kids
videoDescription: Swimming has both physical and mental wellbeing benefits for every age group, but the lifeskill/sport helps children in particular in many ways.

videoTitle: Meow Wolf: Way more than your average selfie museum
videoDescription: Pioneers in interactive art, the creators behind Meow Wolf hope visitors make meaningful connections and do more than just take selfies at their exhibitions.

videoTitle: Why do volcanoes erupt?

videoTitle: Do the 1990s hold the key to sustainable websites?

videoTitle: A Trip To Northern Japan
videoDescription:
Let's face the facts. Japan is a popular place.

With close to 30 million international travelers heading there in 2018, tourists visiting traditional hotspots such as Tokyo, Kyoto and Osaka during peak travel periods -- say, cherry blossom season in the spring -- will find themselves battling overwhelming crowds.

But the northern region of Tohoku remains surprisingly undertraveled in comparison, making it a fantastic destination any time of year.
Located at the tip of Japan's main island of Honshu, Tohoku is made up of six prefectures: Aomori, Akita, Fukushima, Iwate, Miyagi and Yamagata, all of which are filled with dramatic landscapes, historical attractions and culinary delights.

videoTitle: 3 Mysteries of the Universe — and a New Force That Might Explain Them | Alex Keshavarzi | TED
videoDescription:
We're still in the dark about what 95 percent of our universe is made of — and the standard model for understanding particle physics has hit a limit. What's the next step forward? Particle physicist Alex Keshavarzi digs into the first results of the Muon g-2 experiment at Fermilab in Chicago, which found compelling evidence of new particles or forces existing in our universe — a finding that could act as a window into the subatomic world and deepen our understanding of the fabric of reality.

From educating female entrepreneurs on how to launch life-sustaining businesses to murals, billboards and other creative ways of sharing vital resources, Alexander shares how she and her team at the Carter Center connect people to the information they need — when they need it the most.

videoDescription:

Author Suleika Jaouad's experience detailed in the documentary "American Symphony," an intimate portrait of her life as she grapples with illness, is a testament to finding a pathway to healing through artistic expression. In this sweeping conversation with TED's Susan Zimmerman, Jaouad reveals how following curiosity can lead to inspiration — even when it feels like there is none to be found.

videoTitle: How to Close the Authority Gap | Mary Ann Sieghart | TED
videoDescription:
Women are routinely underestimated, overlooked, interrupted, talked over or mistaken for someone more junior at the workplace. Author Mary Ann Sieghart calls this the "authority gap" — all the ways women are (still) taken less seriously than men, despite proven competence and expertise. She explains how we can close this pernicious gap and why everyone wins when we do so.

Drawing on groundbreaking research, archaeologist David Wengrow challenges traditional thinking about the social evolution of humanity -- from the invention of agriculture to the formation of cities and class systems -- and explains how rethinking history can radically change our perspective on inequality and modern life.

videoTitle: Yuval Noah Harari: The Actual Cost of Preventing Climate Breakdown | TED
videoDescription:
Nobody really knows how much it would cost to avoid the worst impacts of climate change. Yet historian Yuval Noah Harari's analysis, based on the work of scientists and economists, indicates that humanity might avert catastrophe by investing the equivalent of just two percent of global GDP into climate solutions. He makes the case that preventing ecological cataclysm will not require the major global disruptions many fear and explains that we already have the resources we need -- it's just a matter of shifting our priorities.

videoTitle: A Brain Implant That Turns Your Thoughts Into Text | Tom Oxley | TED
videoDescription:
What if you could control digital devices using just the power of thought? That's the incredible promise behind the Stentrode -- an implantable brain-computer interface that collects and wirelessly transmits information directly from the brain, without the need for open surgery. Neurotech entrepreneur Tom Oxley describes the intricacies of this breakthrough technology, which is currently enrolling participants in human trials, as well as how it could help restore dignity to those with disabilities -- and transform the future of communication.

videoTitle: How the James Webb Space Telescope Will Unfold the Universe | John C. Mather | TED
videoDescription:
The James Webb Space Telescope is a miracle of modern science and engineering. With a 21-foot, gold-coated mirror protected by a sunshield that's the size of a tennis court, it's the world's most powerful telescope and humanity's latest attempt to answer questions like: "Where did we come from?" and "Are we alone?" (It also needed to be folded up like origami in order to launch into space.) Nobel Laureate John C. Mather, the leader of the team at NASA that built the Webb, explains how the telescope will observe the first galaxies to form in the early universe, peer behind clouds of cosmic dust and gas to reveal stars being born and uncover new details about places like Europa and Titan, which could harbor life. "We're going to get a great surprise from this telescope," Mather says.

videoTitle: We Can Make COVID-19 the Last Pandemic | Bill Gates | TED
videoDescription:
Building a pandemic-free future won’t be easy, but Bill Gates believes that we have the tools and strategies to make it possible -- now we just have to fund them. In this forward-looking talk, he proposes a multi-specialty Global Epidemic Response and Mobilization (GERM) team that would detect potential outbreaks and stop them from becoming pandemics. By investing in disease monitoring, research and development as well as improved health systems, Gates believes we can “create a world where everyone has a chance to live a healthy and productive life -- a life free from the fear of the next COVID-19.”

videoTitle: Ilissa Ocko: The fastest way to slow climate change now | TED Countdown
videoDescription:
"Cutting methane is the single fastest, most effective opportunity to reduce climate change risks in the near term," says atmospheric scientist Ilissa Ocko. That's because, unlike carbon dioxide, methane's warming power doesn't come from a gradual buildup over time but is almost entirely from recent emissions. Ocko identifies three main sources of methane pollution which, if addressed, could dramatically slow down the rate of global warming within years -- not decades. "This is the methane moment," Ocko says.

For anyone who believes poetry is stuffy or elitist, Amanda Gorman -- the youngest inaugural poet in US history -- has some characteristically well-chosen words. Poetry is for everyone, she says, and at its core it's all about connection and collaboration. In this fierce talk and performance, she explains why poetry is inherently political, pays homage to her honorary ancestors and stresses the value of speaking out despite your fears. "Poetry has never been the language of barriers," Gorman says. "It's always been the language of bridges."

"When you see something that's not right or fair or just, you have to say something," Lewis says. "You have to do something." (This conversation is part of the TED Legacy Project. videoTitle: Mentalism, mind reading and the art of getting inside your head | Derren Brown | TED
videoDescription:
"Magic is a great analogy for how we edit reality and form a story -- and then mistake that story for the truth," says psychological illusionist Derren Brown. In a clever talk wrapped around a dazzling mind-reading performance, Brown explores the seductive appeal of finding simple answers to life's complex and subtle questions.
